Sona’s parents are involved in agriculture, which is the main source of income for her family. It is very difficult for the family to cover their daily costs and save money for Sona’s education. This is why Sona has applied for this loan to pay for tuition fees for the first semester.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees for the first semester.

loans.name: Adrian

texts.en:
Adrian is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in silver and gemstone jewelry.  He would like to invest in the purchase of gemstones and raw silver to continue production.  Adrian has been selling through NOVICA since 2010.  This is his story:

"In jewelry, I've found a medium of bodily expression.  In the School of Fine Arts, I learned to express my ideas with a brush and oils.  I can also do so through silver, gold and precious stones.  I live in Peru doing what I love most, and I am passionate about jewelry.  For me, each piece of jewelry is a work of art, and I'm a perfectionist as I create them.  I hope you enjoy the quality and design of my art."

"I wish to thank everyone involved in this microcredit, because with it I'll be able to increase my production.  I will also be able to work on new designs for all the wonderful women that enjoy wearing my jewelry."

Use the link below to view Adrian's silver and gemstone jewelry on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/7520

loans.use: to purchase gemstones and raw silver to continue production

loans.name: Aziah Group

texts.en:
This group is called Aziah, and it consists of seven ladies who live in Taiz, Yemen. They applied for a loan of 210000 YER from AMB.
Aziah raises sheep. She has been in this line of work for many years. She is 23 years old and single and lives in Taiz, Yemen. She is asking for a youth loan of 30000 YER from AMB to buy sheep for resale. This loan enables her to sell the sheep as well to generate even more income. She hopes to provide a better life to her family. She promises to pay on time and is very grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy sheep for resale.

loans.name: Amarjargal

texts.en: Mrs. Amarjargal is 37 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in the Sukhbaatar district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Her husband, Soronzonbold, is 35 years old and is an interior designer who works in a private construction company. Her daughter, Dolgoonmorongua, goes to kindergarten. She has been working as an assistant worker at a local market for years, and she also works part-time at the construction company her husband works at. She and her husband are planning on starting their own interior design business for local customers. She is asking for a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase starting inventory for her new interior design business. She and her husband are hardworking, honest, and responsible people.

loans.use: to purchase starting inventory for her new interior design business.

loans.name: Aldarmaa

texts.en: Mrs. Aldarmaa is a 35-year-old woman who lives with her husband and two children in Ger in the Govi-Altai province of Mongolia. Her husband Davaatseren has been working as an assistant worker in a wooden furniture manufacturing company for years. Her daughter Angarmaa, who is 14, and her son Purev-Ochir, who is 11, are secondary school students. She has been running a butcher shop since 2003 in a rental counter of a local market. She and her husband are planning to start a new business of furniture manufacturing in their area. She has already built a strong relationship with local suppliers and customers and it will be easier for them to start their new wooden furniture manufacturing business. She is now requesting 3,800,000 MNT to purchase starting inventory for starting their wooden furniture manufacturing business. She and her husband are honest, responsible and hardworking people.

loans.use: to purchase starting inventory for a new wooden furniture manufacturing business

loans.name: Diego

texts.en:
Diego is an artisan in Guatemala who specializes in hand-carved wood art.  He would like to invest in the purchase of cedar, mahogany and granadillo woods, as well as in replacing some tools in his workshop.  Diego has been selling through NOVICA since 2011.  This is his story:

"What I enjoy the most about my work is also my biggest challenge, creating new designs.  Wood is a noble element, totally transformable, that gives you a lot if you know how to work it, treat it and take care of it.  I remember with much gratefulness a companion in the first workshop where I worked.  He took a lot of time to teach me things I never imagined possible to do with my hands.  Now I spend some of my time teaching the young people who work with me."

"I thank you for supporting our type of work and our art; without it, we wouldn’t be able to promote our work and provide properly for our families.  I appreciate your support by way of this microcredit so that we may get ahead in our work.  Being able to purchase the materials and tools we need means the artisans at the workshop can continue their work and we can develop our creativity.  May God bless you all!"

Use the link below to view Diego's hand-carved wood art on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/8047

loans.use: to purchase cedar, mahogany and granadillo woods as well as to replace some tools in his workshop.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en: Julie, 47, is a widow and a mother of six children. Her children are all grown up and independent, and they are between the ages of 19 and 26. Julie lives in the Paynesville South community, called Kpelle town. For the past ten years, she has been selling pepper, vita, salt, onions, and rice at the community market. She loves to do this business because she feels self-reliant.  She received help from her sister to start in this  business. She will use the loan given to her to purchase more vita, salt, onions, and palm oil to increase her sales. Her plan for the future is to become a big business woman.

loans.use: to purchase more vita, salt, onion, and palm oil to increase her sales

loans.name: Suwitra

texts.en:
Suwitra, from Bali, specializes in traditional batik and hand-painted apparel. He would like to invest in the purchase of larger amounts of fabric to expand production.

Suwitra has been selling through NOVICA since 2007. This is his story:

Suwitra designs and creates elegant wearable art through his unique ability to capture nature's beauty in clothing apparel. He masters batik and silk screening techniques as well as hand-painted motifs, which he transforms into colorful sarongs, scarves and stylish clothing.

"I am glad to have the possibility to receive this microcredit. I'll be able to buy the materials I need to build up my stock. Thanks to your support, I have an opportunity to develop my business. I hope this will also lead to more people that will really like my designs. Thank you so very much."

Use the link below to view Suwitra's batik and hand-painted apparel on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/6227

loans.use: to purchase fabric in bulk.

loans.name: Abel

texts.en:
Abel is a Peruvian artisan that specializes in tooled leather furniture and decor accents.  He would like to invest in the purchase of fine leather, wood and various fixtures to continue production.  Abel has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story:

"I have been crafting leather items since I was 16.  My older brother, Hector, taught me.  When I was 23, I opened my own workshop in my house.  I cut and tool fine leather with a distinct style and skill that you won't find in many workshops.  I design many beautiful Inca and colonial motifs, and emboss those upon the leather.  I am especially happy and proud that my products are being sold all over the world through the Internet."

"I would like to thank you for offering me your support through this microcredit.  It will allow me and my team to continue crafting items.  This is a traditional art form that has allowed us to provide our children with an education, and pass down a beautiful art."

Use the link below to view Abel's tooled leather furniture and decor accents on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/951

loans.use: to purchase fine leather, wood and various fixtures to continue production.

loans.name: Jameo

texts.en: Jameo is a 40-year-old married woman who has been excited ever since she got to know about the UGAFODE micro-mortgage loan program. It is cost effective and affordable especially to the low income earners. She is convinced that with this program her dream of a decent house is going to be a reality and she and her children and grandchildren will be well accommodated, unlike in her current structure. She is dedicated to paying her loan installments on time and to building a good relationship with the institution.

loans.use: To complete her house

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is an artisan who specializes in African masks and sculptures. He would like to invest in the purchase of raw materials such as wood, aluminum plates and paints.

Emmanuel has been selling through NOVICA since 2000. This is his story:

"After completing a course in auto mechanics, getting a job was difficult and neither my parents nor I could afford the high cost of the machinery I would need to set up on my own. I struggled while doing odd jobs, but I managed to save what I could until I had enough money to buy a small piece of land and put up a wooden store, but I didn't know what to sell. I started buying finished carvings, and in the evenings I learned to carve these beautiful items. My background in auto mechanics became very useful at this point because of my knowledge in cutting and designing of metals, as well as the skill I learned from my father who was a blacksmith. With constant practice, I entered the world of art. My inspiration comes through dreams, so when I wake up I immediately put the design on paper in order not to lose the idea."

"This new microcredit will go a long way to help build up my stock and grow my business. Thank you so much for your help."

Use the link below to view Emmanuel's African masks and carvings on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/1536

loans.use: to purchase raw materials such as wood, aluminum plates and paints.

loans.name: Jarwolay

texts.en:
Jarwolay is 35 years old.  She is married and the mother of three children between the ages of three and 21 years.  She lives in a community called Peace Island in Jacob Town and all three of her children attend school.

She works very hard in her cook shop, or restaurant, where she sells food.  She works five days a week from 7 AM to 6 PM each day.  Jarwolay prepares cassava, potatoes, grains and palava sauce (a type of stew) to meet customer demand.  Because of the good service she provides to her customers, she makes a profit everyday.  With the profit, she buys more goods and attends to the needs of her children.  

She is requesting a loan in order to purchase more ingredients for her business.  Her plan for the future is to give her children a better education.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients for her business.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
De 47 años María es natural de Santa Rosa, decidió llevar una vida independiente únicamente al lado de sus 4 hijos, 2 de los cuales aún menores requieren todo su apoyo y atención. Es poseedora de una vivienda construida a base de madera en donde desempeña su rol de madre.
Es productora de productos agrícolas, dentro de los cuales esta su producto predilecto que es el cacao orgánico por ser un fruto de  mayor demanda en su región y de fácil crecimiento en la zona teniendo en cuenta todas las atenciones del caso.
Desarrolla sus actividades agrícolas en unas parcelas que adquirió con ayuda de su ex pareja desde hace 20 años pues para lograr obtener los frutos de calidad deseado debe contar con mano de obra adicional por parte de jornaleros del lugar para las distintas tareas complicadas.
Le agrada desempeñar sus actividades en el campo  debido a que le recuerda mucho a las épocas de niña que paso junto a sus padres realizando las mismas actividades , no obstante por el momento el cacao presenta cierta disminución en el precio final que ofrecen sus acopiadores , esperando mejore la situación para la próxima campaña.
Hallándose en el inicio de la campaña cuya cosecha esta proyectada para el próximo año necesita contar con capital para seguir expandiendo sus plantaciones y el respectivo reemplazo de árboles de cacao desfasados, para ello debe contar con plantas de almácigo así como abono orgánico proveniente del guano de isla, a ello es necesario añadirle el precio de la mano de obra  por parte de jornaleros cuyo pago se efectúa por adelantado. Ahora solicita 1,000 mil soles para comprar plantas de almácigo así como el de sacos de abono orgánico, con el dinero restante complementará su capital destinado para efectuar el pago a los jornaleros del lugar para desarrollar las tareas programadas.
texts.en:
At 47-years-old, Maria is a native of Santa Rosa. She decided to lead an independent life with only her four children by her side, two of whom are young and still require her support and attention. She is the owner of a wooden house where she performs her duties as a mother. 

Maria produces agricultural products, among which is her preferred product, organic cacao, because it is a fruit in high demand in her region and it is easily grown in the area considering everything required. She carries out her agricultural activities on parcels of land she acquired with the help of her ex-partner 20 years ago. In order to obtain the quality of fruits that she wants, she must rely on additional help from laborers on site to carry out distinct complicated tasks. 

She likes to work in the fields because it reminds her of times when she was a child together with her parents doing the same activities. However, by the time the cacao is ready there is a certain decrease in the final price offered by stockpilers. She is hoping to improve the situation for the next season.

Finding herself at the start of the season whose harvest is projected for next year, she needs to have capital in order to continue to expand her plantations and to replace old cacao trees respectively. For this reason she needs seedlings, and manure compost from Guano Island. It is also necessary to add the cost of manual labor, whose payment is made in advance. 

Now she is asking for 1000 soles to buy seedlings and bags of compost. The remaining money will be used to supplement the capital to pay the laborers to develop scheduled tasks.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and compost, and to hire workers

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is an artisan who specializes in traditional West African masks. She would like to invest in a bulk purchase of raw materials such as wood, metal plates and paints.

Evelyn has been selling through NOVICA since 2008. This is her story:

"My greatest inspiration is to preserve our rich cultural heritage. Initially, I wasn't using a lot of different materials, but now I use recycled glass and glass beads, aluminum, brass and more. I sit and draw a mask creatively, and come up with the colors that will make it stand out."

"I believe that this microcredit will help me create a bigger stock of products and increase sales. My sincere gratitude to all of you for participating in the funding of this microcredit."

Use the link below to view Evelyn's African masks on the NOVICA site:
http://www.novica.com/kiva/6750

loans.use: to purchase raw materials in bulk.

loans.name: Noé

texts.en: Noé and his family's primary source of income is their dairy farm. Constantly looking to reduce his costs while hedging himself against an unpredictable market, he is investing in a 40 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester to reduce his natural gas and agrochemical fertilizer expenses. Using the processed waste from his dairy cows, Noé will fertilize the alfalfa and maize used in their feed. Additionally, his family will benefit from the biogas generated in the kitchen and in the bathroom, reducing their dependence on fossil fuels and their associated costs. This loan represents 43% of the total cost of Noé's Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.use: to purchase a 40 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a 20 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Ignacio Antonio

texts.en: Ignacio (pictured with his mother and wife), a dairy farmer, will use his 10 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester to reduce costs and improve yields on his farm. He will process his cow waste to produce fuel for cooking and heating bathwater and for use as fertilizer for the cow feed: alfalfa and maize. This loan represents 43% of the total cost of his Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.use: to purchase a 10 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Benjamín

texts.en: Benjamín represents the future of farming in Mexico.  He is continuing the family tradition but wants to do so while reducing costs and decreasing the environmental impact caused by his animal waste.  Currently, the waste from his six cows is seen as just that - waste.  However, with his eight cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester, this waste will generate fuel and fertilizer, allowing him to lower costs, maintain or improve yields, and reduce the odors and flies associated with manure piles. This loan represents 43% of the cost of his Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.use: to purchase an eight cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a 25 cubic meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Marie Madeleine

texts.fr: Marie est une femme célibataire qui vit dans un qartier de la capital. Elle tient un restaurant depluis deux ans où elle propose divers plats. Grace à son dynamisme elle s'est faite une clientèle dont elle aimerait continuer de satisfaire. Pour cela, elle sollicite un prêt dans l'otique d'augmenter son stock de nourriture et de boissons. Les bénéfices tirés de ce prêt lui permettront d'assurer la pérennité de son entreprise tout en subvenant aux besoins de ses frères.
texts.en: Marie is a single woman who lives in a neighborhood in the capital. She has been running a restaurant for two years, where she serves diverse dishes. Due to her high energy, she has built a clientele she’d like to continue to satisfy. In order to do this, she is seeking a loan to increase her stock of food and beverages. The profits from this loan will allow her to ensure the longevity of her business while meeting the needs of her brothers.

loans.use: to increase her stock of food and beverages

loans.name: Lamentation  De Geremy Group

texts.fr:
Edma est la coordinatrice de son groupe Lamentation de Geremy. Elle habite dans la région de Trou-du-Nord d’Haïti où de l’électricité est rare et de l’eau est très limitée. Elle a dirigé son commerce de vente de charbon pendant les 4 dernières années. 

Elle voudrait utiliser cet emprunt pour investir dans le charbon, elle a acheté du bois pour le charbon. Des autres membres du groupe ont besoin d’un emprunt pour tels commerces comme vendre des produits alimentaires, cosmétiques, vêtements, chaussureset du charbon. Edma dit que son défi principal est en mesure de vendre plus depuis la crise économique en Haïti ne reçoit pas beaucoup d'argent.
texts.en:
Edma is the coordinator of her group, Lamentation de Geremy. She lives in the Trou-du-Nord region in Haiti, where electricity is rare and water is very limited. She has been running her charcoal-selling business for the last four years.

She would like to use this loan to invest in charcoal; she has bought wood for the charcoal. Some other members of the group need a loan for businesses such as selling food products, cosmetics, clothing, shoes, and charcoal. Edma says that her main challenge is to be able to sell more during the economic crisis in Haiti, where there isn’t a lot of money.

loans.use: to buy wood for charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy and stock canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Flor

texts.es:
Flor es una joven de 18 años que comparte una vida conyugal con Renán también de 18 años, ambos decidieron iniciarse desde jóvenes impulsados por el amor y la confianza única que hallaron entre si, como fruto de su relación tienen hoy a una preciosa niña de nombre Asulda de un año de edad para quien dirigen sus futuros objetivos. Temporalmente viven en una vivienda de adobe en calidad de alquiler.
Desde hace 2 años viene junto a Renán dedicándose a actividades agrícolas en unas parcelas que sus padres le brindaron por tratarse de una pareja joven y con muchos deseos de superación. Tienen como producto principal el cacao orgánico debido a ser un producto de mucha estabilidad en la zona, como todo inicio tuvieron ciertas dificultades al momento de lograr una estabilidad económica para el futuro familiar.
Lo alentador es que a pesar de iniciarse con poco capital han logrado cubrir con todos los gastos familiares básicos considerando que ya poseen una responsabilidad que es su pequeña, no obstante el trabajar en conjunto ha sido una gran herramienta de unión pues la comprensión y la armonía familiar priman en su entorno familiar.
Hace poco recibió una propuesta por parte de una comerciante del lugar quien le ofreció su tienda en calidad de alquiler por un buen tiempo ya que planea retirarse de viaje por diversos motivos, considerando una buena oportunidad planea tomarla y así paralelo al campo con su pareja a cargo espera aportar a la economía familiar.
Tiene muchos deseos a futuro dentro de los cuales está el de seguir estudios superiores en la carrera de farmacia ya que se siente en la capacidad de cumplirla en un tiempo no muy lejano. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, se siente muy agradecida por la oportunidad brindada que ya considera es el motor que necesita actualmente para cumplir sus objetivos comerciales con mayor fluidez. Agradece a sus compañeros de su  banco comunal por la gran oportunidad que le brindan y por la acogida comprometiéndose a cumplir con todos los acuerdos estipulados.
Con los 500 nuevos soles complementará su capital que tiene destinado para el pago del primer mes del alquiler de una pequeña tienda de abarrotes que manejará en adelante.
texts.en:
Flor, 18, shares her married life with Renán, also 18.  They decided to start together from a young age, driven by love and the special trust between them.  As a fruit of their relationship they have a precious little girl named Asulda, age 1, to whom they direct their future goals.  They live temporarily in an adobe house, which they rent.

For two years she has made a living with Renán in agricultural work on some plots of land her parents gave her because they're a young couple with a great desire to improve themselves.  Their main crop is organic cacao because it's very stable in the area.  As in any beginning they had certain problems trying to achieve financial stability for the future family.

What's encouraging is that, in spite of starting out with little capital, they've managed to cover all the basic family expenses, considering that they already have the responsibility of their little girl.  Nevertheless, working together has been a great tool for unity because understanding and family harmony prevail in their family environment.

A little while ago she received a proposal from a merchant in the area who offered to rent her his store for a long time because he plans to take a trip for a variety of reasons.  She considers it a good opportunity and plans to take it.  So she hopes to contribute to the family finances along with the field work with her husband in charge.

She has many desires for the future, including studying pharmacy at the advanced level because she feels she's capable of doing that in the near future.

This is her first loan with MFP.  She's very grateful for this opportunity, which she considers the motivation she needs right now to realize her commercial objectives more fluidly.  She's grateful to her colleagues in her communal bank for the great opportunity they're giving her and for their welcome, and she's committing herself to complying with all the stipulated agreements.

With the 500 nuevos soles [PEN] she'll supplement the capital she has dedicated to paying the first month's rent on a small grocery store that she'll manage from now on.

loans.use: to rent a store to sell products

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née vers 1975 à Sikasso, Madame Mariam est veuve et mère de 3 enfants qui réside chez son feu époux avec ses enfants, dans une famille nucléaire à Wayerma dans la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Mariam, après plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initiée depuis plus de dix années à cette activité de petit commerce notamment à l’achat vente de vêtements, de sacs à main,  de tissus brodés, de pagnes, etc.). Elle achète ses marchandises à Bobo Dioulasso ( Burkina Faso) avant de les revendre à sa place au grand marché de Sikasso où ses marchandises sont beaucoup sollicitées de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement des des femmes de ménages et vendeuses de du marché) pour leur qualité.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décide d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui elle est à son premier prêt. Ainsi, elle sollicite ce crédit pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter, 30 pièces de pagne wax, 20 complets de tissus brodé et 20 sacs à main. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born around 1975 in Sikasso, Ms. Mariam is a widow and the mother of three children. She resides in her deceased husband's home with her children in a nuclear family located in Wayerma, in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After several unsuccessful businesses, Ms. Mariam was introduced to small-scale commerce over ten years ago and particularly in the buying and selling of clothing, handbags, embroidered cloth, 'pagnes' (the colorful cloth of western Africa), etc.  She purchases her merchandise in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso) and then resells it from her spot at the big market of Sikasso where her merchandise is much in demand by her customers (composed essentially of housekeepers retailers at the market) for its quality. 

Concerned about further satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her first loan. Thus, she is requesting this loan to increase her business capital for buying: 30 lengths of Wax 'pagne' cloth, 20 sets of embroidered fabrics, and 20 handbags. 

She envisions making a monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used to help cover family expenses and pay the loan interest. And the rest will be invested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase clothing

loans.name: Assata

texts.fr:
Madame Assata  est née vers 1977 à Sikasso, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit avec son époux dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou II, le centre ville de Sikasso. 
Madame Assata est enseignante de formation, à défaut de pratiquer cette profession elle s’est initiée à cette activité d’achat et vente des  laits frais, laits cailles et yaourts depuis 10 années. Elle mène son activité dans un kiosque situé dans son quartier de Sikasso et de façon ambulante. Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ une année. Elle est à son premier prêt.
 Elle sollicite ce premier prêt individuel dans le but d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter 100 litres de lait frais pour en transformer en lait caillés et en yaourt afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 10 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Assata was born around 1977 in Sikasso. She is married and the mother of five children. She lives with her husband in a large traditional extended family in Sanoubougou II, the downtown of Sikasso City. Ms. Assata is a teacher by training. Instead of practicing this profession, she became familiar with the buying and selling of fresh milk, curdled milk, and yoghurt ten years ago. She operates in a kiosk located in her district in Sikasso and by going door to door. 

Concerned about further satisfying her burgeoning customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso about a year ago. She in on her first loan. She is requesting this individual loan with the goal of increasing her business capital, so as to purchase 100 liters of fresh milk for processing into curds and yoghurt. This is to do better in satisfying her burgeoning customer base.

With this loan, she envisions making a monthly profit of 10,000 francs CFA that will be used to help cover family expenses and pay the loan interest. And the rest will invested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase fresh milk

loans.name: Maminata

texts.fr:
Née vers 1969 à Sikasso, Madame Maminata est mariée et mère de quatre enfants, elle vit chez son époux avec ses enfants dans une famille nucléaire à Lafiabougou, dans la ville de Sikasso.
Madame Maminata après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initiée depuis plus de cinq ans à cette activité génératrices de revenus. Elle jouit d’une grande réputation dans son lieu d’achat et vente des condiments à la maison et au marché de Lafiabougou dont elle dispose une place.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cessait d’accroitre, elle décide de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son premier prêt individuel.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 seaux de pâtes d’arachide, 3 cartons magie, 2 cartons concentrée tomate,  3 sacs d’oignons et 5 cartons de moutarde) à Sikasso 
Madame Maminata vend  au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de tous les couches sociales. 
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qui sera utiliser pour réaliser pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born around 1969 in Sikasso, Ms. Maminata is marred and the mother of four children. She lives at her husband's place with her children in a nuclear family located in Wayerma, in Sikasso City. After several unsuccessful businesses, Ms. Maminata was introduced to this revenue-generating business over five years ago. She enjoys a great reputation locally buying and selling condiments at the house and at the Lafiabougou market, where she has a spot. 

Concerned about further satisfying her ever-growing customer base, she decided to join the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her first individual loan. This loan will be used to purchase: 5 pails of peanut butter, 3 boxes of Magie [bouillon cubes], 2 boxes of tomato paste, 2 sacks of onions, and 5 boxes of mustard, in Sikasso. 

Accepting cash or credit, Ms. Maminata makes her sales to customers from all walks of life. With this loan, she envisions making a monthly profit of 90,000 francs CFA that will be used to help cover family expenses and pay the loan interest. And the rest will be invested in her business.

loans.use: to purchase condiments

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née vers 1963 à N’Kourala préfecture de Sikasso, Madame Mariam est veuve et mère de quatre enfants qui réside à Médine-Sikasso. 
Madame Mariam après avoir perdu son époux, s’est initiée au domaine du commerce notamment à l’achat vente de condiments. Elle vend au nouveau de marché de Médine où elle dispose d’un magasin et où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ deux années. Ainsi elle a bénéficié trois crédits qui ont été tous remboursés avec succès. Alors dans but de toujours mieux se relancer dans même activité, elle sollicite ce quatrième crédit qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour pouvoir acheter, 15 sacs de tomates fraîches, 15 sacs d’oignons de graines différentes et de stock de condiments.
Ses marchandises sont achetées sur place avec les paysans venus des villages environnants et  ramenées pour vente dans les marchés hebdomadaires de Yorosso et Kouri vers la frontière Mali-Burkina Faso, en détail et en gros au comptant les jours de foire à une clientèle composée essentiellement de forains.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 110 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en: Born around 1963 in the N’Kourala prefecture of Sikasso, Mrs. Mariam is a widowed mother of four children who lives in Médine-Sikasso. After having lost her husband, Mrs. Mariam started selling food condiments. She sells at the Médine market, where she has a store, and where she is heavily sought after by her clientele for the quality of her products. In order to satisfy her growing clientele, she decided to join microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago. She has already benefited from three loans, which have all been successfully repaid. In the goal of continuing to improve her business, she is seeking a fourth loan, which will allow her to increase her business funds to be able to buy 15 sacks of fresh tomatoes, 15 sacks of onions, different grains, and a stock of condiments. Her products are bought on the spot by farmers coming from neighboring villages and brought back to sell in the weekly markets in Yorosso and Kouri near the Mali-Burkina Faso border, for retail and wholesale for credit on fair days to a clientele composed essentially of fairground people. She envisions earning with this loan a monthly profit of 110,000 FCFA, which will be used to contribute to family expenses, pay interest on her loan, and reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy food condiments

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for maintenance.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stock of beverages to resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of the pump boat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stock of canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Genevieve

texts.en:
Genevieve is from Campo 1, Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur. She's married and has two children. To earn a living, she raises pigs for sale. Every month, she earns about PHP 19,974. 

In 2011, she joined GDMPC. She has applied for a loan of PHP 40,000 from the cooperative. She will use the loan to purchase livestock feed and other supplies for raising pigs. She plans to buy more piglets to raise and eventually sell, to make good cash income.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies for raising pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy stocks of canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: John

texts.en: I Dream of Johnny was established in June of 2000 by owner JCM. The business manufactures and distributes customized and personalized apparel and accessories for babies. The company exhibits its products in showrooms in Los Angeles, New York, Chicago and Texas. Clients range from wholesalers to retail stores across the USA, with 20% of annual sales coming from exports to Canada. There is growing demand for I Dream of Johnny products due to quick order turnaround time. I Dream of Johnny was recently approved to manufacture apparel using licensed logos from various universities. I Dream of Johnny has received orders from Barnes and Noble bookstores at Boston University and from the Harvard University Trademark Program for these licensed logo products. This microloan will be used to fill these two large orders helping I Dream of Johnny maintain its quick order turnaround time and preserve its competitive advantage in a highly competitive retail market.

loans.use: to purchase inventory in order to fill two large orders for apparel.

loans.name: Erdenekhuyag

texts.en:
Erdenekhuyag is 38 years old and lives with his family in their wooden house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital. His house is located in the boundary area of the city with no water, minimal roads and spotty electricity. Erdenekhuyag‘s family consists of four people: himself, his wife and two children who are students. In 2008 they bought the land and built a 60-square-meter wooden house. 
Since 2003, Erdenekhuyag has had a micro bus with 14 seats and with his wife runs a transportation business between Ulaanbaatar and a province 800 km away. He runs three times minimum in a month to Zavkhan province. 
As his children grow the house is feeling smaller. Therefore Erdenekhuyag is planning to expand his house by building a new floor with wood and laying bricks on the outer side of the walls in order to stop the heat loss through the walls. By doing this Erdenekhuyag’s family can improve their living condition and will have a spacious house that will serve them the rest of their life.

loans.use: to expand his house

loans.name: Melvin

texts.en:
Melvin is married with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Melvin is 41 years old and all of her children are in school.

She has a business selling native bags in the Philippines. Melvin requested a 11,000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to purchase more native bags to sell to customers.

She has been in this business for six years. In the future, Melvin would like to save enough money so she continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more native bags to sell to customers.

loans.name: Carolina

texts.en:
This time, for her eighth cycle loan, Carolina is applying for a loan of 10,000 PHP to buy fruits, vegetables and charcoals to sell at her stall.  
The charcoal retail business that she previously funded through Kiva partners and NWTF continues and provides for Carolina and her family with income that is improving their standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
As the married mother of four children, Juliet works hard to support her family. She has a fishing business in the Philippines and also earns additional income from fattening pigs. Juliet is borrowing 20,000 Philippine pesos through NWTF to buy fishing net and other equipment for her fishing business.

Juliet has been sustaining her business activities through her past five loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business and continuing to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy fishing net and other equipment.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
This is Leonora, 52, resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Wilfredo and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband,manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Leonora operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Leonora hopes to expand her business and dreams to give her children a good and quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Jeshty

texts.en:
Jeshty is a 32 year old married woman and a mother of two young children ages eight and four. She earns a living through her store. She sells various goods and commodities like pants, shirts, belts, shoes and other fashion accessories. This is the source of her income. 
Jeshty works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of the family especially for the schooling of her children. As of now, Jeshty is in need of additional capital for the expansion of her business. She is asking for a loan to buy more products to sell such as pants, shirts, shoes and other fashion accessories. With this, she will be able to increase her stocks and attract more customers and buyers into her store, thus augmenting her sales and income.

loans.use: to buy more products to sell such as pants, shirts, shoes and other fashion accessories

loans.name: Henrylin

texts.en:
Henrylin is 35 years old and married with four children. Three of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Henrylin has a fishing business in the Philippines. She requested a 12,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to buy fishing net, bamboo, binder and other fishing equipment.

Henrylin has been in this business for seven years. In the future, Henrylin would like to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing net, bamboo, binder and other fishing equipment.

loans.name: Luisita

texts.en:
Luisita is a 57-year-old married woman and a mother of four grown up children from Ubay, Bohol. Her husband is a habal-habal, or motorcycle transport, driver. Luisita has been engaged in a hog-raising business for several years now. 

Luisita is asking for a loan to buy a new tire for the motorcycle and feed for her pigs.

In the future, Luisita dreams of making her business a success.

loans.use: to buy a new tire for her motorcycle and feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Issifou

texts.fr:
Monsieur ISSIFOU est né vers 1969 à Gningoni, il est père de 5 enfants et vit dans sa famille nucléaire à  Kadiolo (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
 ISSIFOU mène cette activité de commercialisation de céréales depuis quatre ans. Son expérience dans ce domaine, lui a valu une bonne réputation et reçoit des commandes de céréales, notamment du maïs. Ainsi pour avoir les ressources nécessaires afin de satisfaire ses clients, il décida de collaborer avec l’Institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Il est à son cinquième prêt et tous les prêts passés ont été correctement remboursés.
Ce prêt lui permettra d’acheter, 2 tonnes de maïs et 1 tonne de mil. Il s’approvisionne dans les villages avoisinants Kadiolo. Les céréales sont stockées avant de les revendre au comptant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes venant des grandes villes telles SIKASSO, BAMAKO ET KOUTIALA. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 90 000 FCFA. Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Issifou was born around 1969 in Gningoni.  He is the father of five children and he lives in a nuclear family in Kadiolo (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

He has been selling grains for the past four years.  Thanks to his experience in this field, he enjoys a good reputation as a seller and he receives orders for grains, particularly maize.  In order to have the necessary resources to satisfy his customers' needs, Issifou decided to collaborate with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  This is his fifth loan, and all previous loans have been duly repaid.

This loan will help him to buy two tonnes of maize and one tonne of millet.  He buys grains from villages around Kadiolo and stores his merchandise before reselling it for cash.  His customer base consists of men and women who come from major cities such as Sikasso, Bamako and Koutiala.

Thanks to this loan, Issifou is expecting average monthly profits to reach 90,000 CFA francs.  He will use these profits to pay his loan's interest, and will invest the rest of the money in his business.

loans.use: to buy grains.

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
As a married mother of six children, Lourdes works hard to support her family.

She has a selling firewood business in the Philippines, and earns additional income from farming vegetables. Lourdes is borrowing PHP 13000 through NWTF to purchase more firewood to sell.

Lourdes has been sustaining her business activities through her past six loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more firewood to sell.

loans.name: Caren

texts.en:
Caren is a small-scale farmer from Mabonde location, Kitale town in western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for the last three years and has solely relied on the income from her farm to cater to the needs of her family. Her mixed farm produces maize and milk which are all sold to the local market. 

Caren is 27 years old and married with one child, 3 years old.

She has requested a loan of 41,600 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help her expand her business and secure a great future for her child. Her biggest challenge has been competition and poor market prices for her farm produce.

She is grateful for the financial support and appreciates Juhudi for its efficiency in providing financial services.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Cleophas

texts.en:
Cleophas is 24 years old and married. He is a small-scale farmer from Kitale county in western Kenya. He has been practicing mixed farming for five years now and has one employee. He sells his farm produce, which includes milk and eggs, to the local market. He solely depends on the income from his farm to meet his basic needs. He faces the challenge of diseases which affects his poultry farm and lowers his egg production.

Cleophas has made a loan request of 31,200 KES ( Kenyan shillings) to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help him improve the livelihood of his young family. He hopes to expand his dairy farm by acquiring additional dairy cows in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Dorika

texts.en:
Dorika is 53 years old, married and has six children between 32 and 11 years old. Three of the children are currently attending school. She is a resident of Saboti Location, Kitale county in western Kenya. She has been practicing mixed farming for the past seven years. Her farm produces milk, eggs and vegetables which are all sold locally. 

She has made a loan request of 62,400 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi KIlimo in order to purchase and insure dairy cow. This loan will help her acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. She will use the proceeds from the sale of milk to expand her farming and pay school fees for her children. Her biggest challenges have been diseases and lack of enough animal feed during the dry seasons.

loans.use: to puchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 34 years old, married and has three children who all attend school. She is a small-scale farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya where she has been farming for 10 years now. Her mixed farm produces maize, milk, vegetables and beans which are all sold locally. She is also a teacher at a local school in the same town. Judith, pictured at her sukuma wiki (vegetable) farm, has always been passionate about farming and has no regrets at all in investing in this type of business.

She has made her first loan request of 41,600 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable her to acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help improve the livelihood of her family. She is planning to expand her dairy farm by acquiring at least six quality dairy cows able to produce at least 20 litres of milk daily. Her primary challenge has been poor market prices for her farm produce.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 30 years old and married with two children. He is a horticultural farmer and has been in this business for the last three years, earning a monthly income of KES 30,000. 

He is servicing his first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET LTD and this will help him purchase farming inputs, such as fertilizer and pesticides.
He hopes to use anticipated profits to expand his farm and reinvest. 

His dream is to improve his family's living standards and to educate his children

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.name: Dinah

texts.en: Dinah, age 52 and single, is from Sinusa, Ozamis City. Dinah has been in the gardening business for 10 years, and she earns 5,000 PHP a month. Dinah joined GDMPC in 2011. Dinah is requesting a loan of 7,500 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living condition of her family.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Marissa

texts.en:
This is Marissa, 41, a resident of Dasmariñas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Urbano, a company driver, and she is a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
Marissa has a dishwashing liquid business. She buys the ingredients and mixes them to make a dishwashing liquid. She then puts it into bottles, retails it and distributes the product to some variety stores. She also sells them to her neighbors and in the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 6,000 in weekly sales.
To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000. She will be utilizing the loan to buy bottles and ingredients to make her dishwashing liquid. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 
Marissa hopes to give her children a good quality education and dreams to expand her business through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for ingredients like soap flakes, essential oils, glycerin, and other chemicals needed in her product.

loans.name: Lourgen

texts.en: Lourgen is 47 years old. She is married with three dependents. They live in Clarin, Misamis Occidental. Lourgen cultivates bananas to sell. She has been in this work for 15 years. She gets a monthly income of 5,000 PHP. In 2011, she became a member of GDMPC. She has applied for a loan of 10,500 PHP from the cooperative to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Lourgen is planning to set aside a portion of the income generated from this loan to buy a new freezer for the store.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise

loans.name: Galina

texts.ru:
Галина живет в Новой Каховке. Она занимается торговлей бельем, носками, колготками и прочим мелким товаром на одном из рынков города. Товар у Галины ходовой, у нее ест своя группа постоянных клиентов. 
Галина надеется использовать кредит в размере 15 000 гривен для того, чтобы пополнить ассортимент белья, носков, колготок, на которые появился дополнительный спрос.
texts.en:
Galina lives in the Novaya Kahovka. She is in the business of selling underwear, socks, stockings and other small items on one of the town markets. Galina's merchandise is popular and she has a group of regular customers.

Galina hopes to use the loan in the amount of 15,000 hryvnia to stock up on the assortment of underwear, socks and stockings for which there's additional demand.

loans.use: to fulfill the assortment of underwear, socks, stockings which get additional demand.

loans.name: Olga

texts.ru:
Ольга уже несколько раз пользовалась кредитными услугами КИВА. Благодаря предыдущему кредиту Ольга смогла недорого купить б/у арки для теплиц и закончить постройку двух больших теплиц, а также значительно увеличить доход с огорода и приобрести мотоблок для обработки земли. Более того семья смогла позволить себе приобрести также недорогой автомобиль местного производства. 
В этот раз Ольге необходима сумма в размере 20 000 гривен для того, чтобы установить отопление в теплицы: купить котел на 10 000 гривен и шланги для его установки – 10 000 гривен. Это даст возможность торговать более ранними овощами по более высокой цене. На данный момент один из основных насущных вопросов для Ольги – это удалённость от трассы и рынка, что усложняет процесс вывоза продукции. Иногда Ольге приходится договариваться с кем-то из соседей, чтобы вывезти товар. Со временем Ольга надеется приобрести транспортное средство для бизнеса и тем решить этот наболевший вопрос.
texts.en:
Olga has used Kiva's loan services several times. Thanks to the previous loan Olga was able to buy used arches for the greenhouse and complete the building of two large greenhouses as well as significantly increase revenue from the garden and buy a tractor for cultivation of land. Moreover the family could afford to buy an inexpensive vehicle of local make.

This time Olga needs a loan in the amount of 20,000 hryvnia to install heating in the greenhouse: to buy a boiler for 10,000 hryvnia and hoses for installation costing 10,000 hryvnia. This will give her the opportunity to sell early vegetables at a higher price. At this time one of the major current issues for Olga is the long distance from the road and the market which makes it difficult to export products. Sometimes she has to ask some of the neighbors to transport the produce. Over time Olga hopes to purchase a vehicle for business to solve this urgent problem.

loans.use: to install heating in the greenhouse.

loans.name: Nikolai

texts.ru:
Николай живет в Каменке. Он занимается тепличным хозяйством, выращивая ранние овощи и цветы на продажу на собственном участке земли. Этим бизнесом Николай занимается вместе с женой вот уже 30 лет.  
На полученные дополнительные средства в размере 24 000 он хочет построить дополнительную теплицу: дороже всего обойдётся арматура, которая стоит примерно 24 000 гривен. Николай планирует развивать своё дело, со временем хочет ставить еще теплицы, а также открыть небольшой цветочный магазин на автовокзале вместо ларька, который у них сейчас есть там.
texts.en:
Nikolai lives in Kamenka. He is a greenhouse farmer and uses his own plot of land to cultivate early vegetables and flowers for sale. Nikolai and his wife have been engaged in this business for the past 30 years.

Using the additional funds of 24,000 hryvnia, Nikolai would like to build a new greenhouse. The most expensive part of the project will be the greenhouse framework, which will cost roughly the entire amount of this loan.

Nikolai is planning to continue developing his business and, in time, build additional greenhouses. He also plans to open a small flower shop at the bus station, thereby replacing the stall he currently operates there.

loans.use: to build an additional greenhouse

loans.name: Galina

texts.ru:
Галина занимается фермерским хозяйством, выращивает ранние овощи под реализацию. Вместе с мужем Галина занимается этим делом уже более 20 лет. Бизнес приносит дополнительный доход, понемногу развивается. 
Галина планирует вложить 10 000 гривен, полученные от КИВА, в ремонт теплицы перед новым сезоном, а также надеется приобрести газовый котёл, чтобы доделать отопление в теплицах и купить навоз в качестве удобрения. Со временем мечтают сделать ремонт в собственном доме и приобрести кондиционер для семьи.
texts.en:
Galina is a farmer and cultivates early vegetables for sale. Together with her husband, she has been in this business for over 20 years. The business brings them additional income and is gradually expanding.

Galina plans to invest the 10,000 hryvnia from Kiva into repairs of a greenhouse in advance of the new season. She also hopes to purchase a gas boiler to finalize the construction of the greenhouse heating system, and to buy manure for use as fertilizer. Galina and her husband dream that in time they will be able to carry out repairs in their home and buy an air conditioner for their family.

loans.use: to repair a greenhouse and install a greenhouse heating system

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella, a 32-year-old married woman, has 5 children and operates a small retail shop in one of the busy trading centers on the outskirts of Lyantonde town. She works 7 days a week so that she can maximize profits. Her main challenge is limited capital and competition from the neighboring retail traders. Often, her customers ask her for goods she does not have, apparently because she cannot afford them. With the previous loan, she was able to stock some of them, like cooking utensils and other household items. Her honesty and good customer service have helped her to have an edge over some of her competitors. She is confident that with this loan she will be able to make enough profits, since she will have more items--especially with the festive season at hand. She is sure she will make her repayments well. In the picture is Stella (right) with the Ugafode staff.

loans.use: to buy more items like sugar, soap, and salt for resale.

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en:
This is Analiza, She previously accessed a 20,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase raw ingredients for her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 20,000 PHP loan that will allow her to buy raw ingredients like sugar, flour, butter and other ingredients. Her profits from her business will definitely help to sustain her family’s daily needs and pay for her children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Analiza hopes her business will grow and dreams of being able to give her children a good future and high-quality education through all her hard work with her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of their work every week. It is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients like flour, sugar, and butter for her business.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan, 51, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Jaime, a driver and the father to her children. Together with her husband, she manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Susan operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue business operations, she is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands.

Susan hopes to expand her business and dreams of having a good life through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Kristine

texts.en:
This is Kristine.  She previously accessed a 40,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase merchandise and different products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another loan of 50,000 PHP to buy more merchandise like electric fans, rice cookers, flat irons, bags and other products needed in her business. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help to cover her family’s daily needs and children’s education expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Kristine hopes to grow her business and dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise and products like electric fans, rice cookers, flat irons, bags and other products

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou is a 42-year-old married woman and a mother of seven children from Ubay, Bohol. She has owned a 'habal-habal' or motorcycle transport business for more than 8 years now.

Marilou is asking for a loan to buy new tires, nuts and bolts and gasoline. With this, she will be able to maintain the good working condition of the motorcycle thus allowing her husband to use it to earn their living.

loans.use: to buy new tires, nuts and bolts and gasoline

loans.name: Saverino

texts.en:
Saverino is a forty-eight-year-old married man with eight children living in Kasese, Uganda. He has been dealing in agriculture for eleven years and works ten hours a day. After realizing that the only lucrative business is agriculture, he decided to buy land and venture into working it and has since reaped tangible benefits. Like most farmers he has challenges of unpredictable seasonal weather changes and has recently been affected by the banana wilt disease devastating his plantation.

His dreams are to educate his children and rehabilitate his banana plantation by cutting down the affected plants and planting new banana stems. Saverino intends to use the loan facility to rehabilitate his banana plantation.

loans.use: to rehabilitate his banana plantation.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is 52 years old. She is a widow and lives alone in Sighnaghi District. The only source of income for Marina is her small monthly salary, working as a servant-maid in a family. 

As her income is not enough for everyday expenses and food, Marina decided to start a new business. She has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for the business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was always rejected, due to lack of experience in a new business and her low income. Experience is usually demanded by local credit providers. 

Her loan request was approved under a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisions providing business start-up and re-startup credits with easier conditions for the country's rural poor, who do not have access to credit products and are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Marina will purchase used clothing and sell it from her house among her neighbors. She will begin her entrepreneurial activity with a wide assortment of merchandise and high sales volume. This will increase her income. She wants to develop her business further and reinvest the increased income in her business. The new business initiative financed with the Kiva start-up loan will significantly improve her living conditions. She is grateful in advance for your support.

loans.use: to purchase used clothing and start up a retail business

loans.name: Jophes

texts.en: Jophes is a 30-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. This father to two children is married and lives in Kagadi, Uganda. He was inspired to the teaching profession by his urge to serve the nation and he feels there is no better way but to teach the children of his nation. He does farming to supplement the low pay from his salary. Jophes intends to use the loan to buy cement and sand for building a residential house.

loans.use: to buy cement and sand for building a residential house.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary, 58, is a small-scale farmer from the fertile land of bananas: Nkubu town in Mt. Kenya Region. She has been farming for the last twenty years, producing maize, beans and horticultural crops which she sells locally. She also operates a retail shop in the same town. She says that farming has always been her hobby and this has made it more successful than she ever imagined. She, like any other farmer, faces the challenges of lack of enough water for her crops and lack of enough capital for expansion.

She has made her first loan request through Juhudi Kilimo for a loan of 40,000 KES in order to purchase irrigation equipment, including water pipes and a pump. This loan will enable her install irrigation equipment at her farm which she can use during the dry season. She says that this will ensure constant production throughout all seasons. The increased production will increase her income and improve her living standards.

Rosemary would like to acquire a pick-up truck in the near future to help transport her produce to the market

loans.use: to buy irrigation equipment.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is a 26-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. A mother to two children, she is married and lives in Kagadi,  Uganda. She was inspired to join the teaching profession by her desire to inspire young people. She also operates a boutique to supplement her meager salary. Agnes is requesting for a loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to pay her children's school fees.

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
This is Emelia. She previously accessed a 10,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities and varieties of grocery items and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education, and they also helped with her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 10,000 PHP loan for her to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add in her inventory. The more items displayed at the store the better. More items to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s education. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Emelia hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving her children a high-quality education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, products and beverages needed in her business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a 46-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. A mother of five children, she is married and lives in Kagadi, Uganda. 

She became a teacher at her parents' urging as she originally wanted to be a secretary. Nonetheless, she has now come to love and appreciate her profession over time.

Juliet sells juice at school to supplement her salary. Her dreams are to see her children attain degrees and to set up a school canteen. Juliet is requesting a loan to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy chickens and chicken feed.

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina earns a living by selling dried fish to the local people at the market. She lives with her husband in Ubay, Bohol, Philippines. She has been in business for more than 30 years now. Her husband works as a fisherman.

Martina is asking for a loan to buy new fishing nets for her husband. She also wants to buy additional fish to dry and sell.

In the future, Martina hopes to expand her business and make it a success.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets.

loans.name: Felista

texts.en: Felista, 41, is a single mother to three children aged between 8 and 16 years. She owns a boutique where she sells clothes and shoes. A resident of Kagadi, Uganda, she has been in this business for 14 years, and she supplements her earnings with rental income from her house. As a divorced mother, she plans to invest in real estate to secure her children’s future. Inadequate capital is a major challenge to her business. Felista intends to use this loan to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Narlina

texts.en:
This is Narlina. She previously accessed an 8,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase more quantities of different supplies and products needed in her business. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and in paying for her family's personal, household and business expenditures. 

Narlina would like to apply for another 15,000 PHP loan to buy more quantities of supplies such as a dust pan, mirror, hanger, pliers and other products for her business. The more items displayed at the store, the better. More items to sell will result in better profits, which will help to sustain her family’s daily needs and her children’s educational expenses. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Narlina hopes to be able to expand her business in the coming years and dreams of giving her children a good and quality education. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group comprises 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stock of supplies such as a dust pan, mirror, hanger, pliers and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 31-year-old government employee who works as a primary school teacher. A father of three children, he is married and lives in Kagadi, Uganda. He has been in the teaching profession for six years. He was inspired to the teaching profession by his desire to associate with young people.

To supplement his meager salary, John has ventured into the produce business. With the proceeds, he has been able to buy land and pay the school fees for his children.

John is requesting a loan to buy agricultural produce such as rice and beans to sell.

loans.use: to buy agricultural produce such as rice and beans to sell.

loans.name: William

texts.en:
William is a 39-year-old, hardworking married man with five children. He and his family live in Kagadi, Uganda. He is a government employee who works as a primary school teacher. He has been in this profession for 20 years. He was inspired to join the teaching profession by his desire to teach.

To supplement his meager salary, William has decided to venture into the produce business. He has found it to be very lucrative. Inadequate capital and poor transportation systems are his major challenges. His business plan is to own a food store where he can supply his customers all year round.

William is requesting a loan to buy agricultural produce such as maize and beans to sell.

loans.use: to buy agricultural produce such as maize and beans to sell.

loans.name: Jean Chrysostome

texts.fr:
Monsieur Jean Chrysostome est marié et est employé de AEE Rwanda.  Agé de 39 ans, il a deux enfants dont le plus âgé a 2 ans et le moins âgé a une année. Aucun de ses enfant ne va à l’école (ils n’ont pas encore atteint l’âge d’aller à l’école) et aucune autre personne n’est en sa charge. 
Il est né au Rwanda et a un niveau d’étude universitaire (A0) en santé publique.
Il a ouvert son compte chez ACB Ltd en 2008 et actuellement est au 3ème cycle de crédit. Les crédits antérieurs sont bien remboursés.
Le crédit lui octroyé sera utilisé pour acheter 4 sacs de ciments, 12 kilos des clous, 16 triplex qu'il utilisera pour faire le finissage de sa maison qu’il mettra en location.  Le non paiement de salaire par son employeur est la seule difficulté qu’attend Monsieur Jean Chrysostome.  Sa stratégie et d’embellir de plus en plus cette maison en fin que les locateurs soient attirés et payer beaucoup de loyers.
Ses ambitions sont les suivantes : pour le travail, il va être ponctuel et évitera des irégularité. Pour sa famille, il va scolariser ses enfants et aménagera sa maison pour habiter dans une belle maison.
texts.en:
Jean Chrysostome is married and an employee of AEE Rwanda. He is 39 years old and has 2 children, the eldest of whom is 2 and the youngest, 1. Neither of his children go to school (they have not yet reached school age) and he is responsible for no other people. He was born in Rwanda and has a university (A0) level education in public health.

He opened his account with ACB Ltd in 2008 and is currently on his 3rd loan cycle. The previous loans have been properly repaid. The loan granted to him will be used to buy 4 bags of cement, 12 kilos of nails and 16 sheets of triple ply-board which he will use to finish off his house that he will then rent out. The only difficulty that Jean Chrysostome expects is the non-payment of his salary by his employer. His strategy is to keep decorating the house so that renters are attracted to it and prepared to pay a high rent. 

He has the following ambitions: concerning work, he will be punctual and avoid irregularities, and concerning his family, he will make sure his children get an education and will develop his house so that he can live in a beautiful home.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, ply-board, nails and planks.

loans.name: Judas

texts.en: Judas, 32, is a married man with five children aged between 1 and 15. He lives in Kagadi, Uganda. Due to his passion to change his and his children's future, he started a produce business ten years ago. He has been able to build rental houses to supplement his produce business income and has also continued to do farming. He dreams of educating his children up to university level and opening up another outlet. Weather changes and bad roads affect his business. Judas intends to use this loan to buy beans and maize to sell.

loans.use: to buy beans and maize to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizer and pay the labourers.

loans.name: Sophie

texts.fr:
Sophie est une dame âgée de 47 ans, célibataire et mère de 03 enfants dont l'âge varie entre 18 et 27 ans et parmi lesquels 02 vont à l'école. la plus âgée malgré ses problèmes d'audition suit néanmoins une formation en couture. la mère de cette dernière Sophie, notre cliente mène une activité de vente des vivres frais dans un marché de la ville depuis 10 ans déjà. elle bénéficie de ce fait d'une bonne expérience dans le domaine, ce qui lui a permis de constituer un portefeuille clientèle considérable. 
elle voudrait avec ce crédit acheter 10 pastèques, un filet d'orange, un filet de pamplemousse, 10 régimes de plantain, 50 têtes d'ananas et un cajot de tomates pour renforcer son stock de marchandises afin de mieux satisfaire sa demande. les bénéfices supplémentaires lui permettront de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Sophie is a 47-year-old woman, the single mother of 3 children aged between 18 and 27, two of whom go to school. Despite her hearing problems, her eldest child is still following a course in sewing. The latter's mother, our customer Sophie, has been selling fresh food at a market in town for 10 years already. She enjoys a good experience in this line of work, which has allowed her to build up a considerable portfolio of clients.
