She would like to use this loan to buy 10 melons, a net of oranges, a net of grapefruit, 10 bunches of plantains, 50 heads of pineapple and a box of tomatoes with which to reinforce her stock, so that she can better meet demand. The additional profits will enable her to better meet her family's needs.

loans.use: to buy fresh food for resale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a 26-year-old married woman with two children living in Masindi, Uganda. She makes a variety of dishes, and with the proceeds she has been able to pay her children's school fees and renovate her house. She has been in business for twelve years, despite the challenge of inadequate capital. Her dreams are to educate children and set up a modern bakery. Fatuma intends to use the loan to buy cooking ingredients such as flour and cooking oil.

loans.use: to buy cooking ingredients such as flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a water tank to catch rainwater to use in watering her crops during the dry season.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
This is Emily, 56, a resident of Payatas, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Onofreg and a mother to her children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Emily operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store that retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. She also has a thrift store. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Php (Philippines pesos) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 14,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Emily hopes to expand her business and dreams to have their own house and lot through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and this is where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, toiletries and beverages needed in her business.

loans.name: Amon

texts.en:
Amon lives in rural western Uganda and is a farmer. He grows coffee, Irish potatoes and sugarcane. He does all this to earn income to sustain his large family and pay school fees. 

He wants the money to buy materials to complete his house, which is inhabitable at the moment. With the loan, his family will have better shelter and enough space to house all his six children, who have had to share beds at the moment.

He is confident he will be a rich man with time. Weather changes and limited capital are his major setbacks.

loans.use: To buy building materials for completing his house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Mario

texts.en:
Mario, a 24-year-old-single Roma man, lives in a major city in central Albania. He’s got future plans and works hard to achieve them. Mario wants to get married, have children and a house of his own, he said with a smile. 

He was in his early 20s when he started buying and selling used clothes at the Roma Market in his city. With the income he has been generating from this activity, he has been able to make a living and help his parents and siblings also.

Now, Mario wants to stock up on more inventories of used items to resell. It will be the first time for him to request a loan through Kiva, but not the first time requesting a loan from VisionFund Albania. He has successfully repaid all previous loans and has gained so much respect from the VFA institution for his responsible nature.

loans.use: To stock up on more inventories of used items to resell.

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima, 29, is married with four children. She lives in Masindi, Uganda. Twelve years ago, she decided to venture into making food to sell in schools and churches, and she has been able to secure a number of loyal customers. The high cost of ingredients and lack of permanent premises are her major challenges, while her dreams are to own a bakery and pay her children's school fees. Halima intends to use this loan to buy baking ingredients such as flour and cooking oil.

loans.use: to buy baking ingredients such as flour and cooking oil.

loans.name: Chelangat

texts.en:
Chelangat is 23 years old, married and blessed with two children that she supports. She has run a general shop for the last three years, making a monthly income of 10,000 KES (Kenyan shillings).

She has applied for her first loan of KES 20,000 from KADET LTD. She plans to purchase home items like laundry soaps, cooking fat and flour for her shop. 

The anticipated profits will be reinvested into the business. Her future plan is to have business success.

loans.use: to buy laundry soaps, cooking fat and flour for her shop.

loans.name: Orgit

texts.en:
Orgit is 28 and married with two children, ages one and two. He and his family are Egyptians. Until four years ago, Orgit lived in Greece and worked in construction. He has since he has returned to his homeland, which is a major city in central Albania. Orgit continues to work in construction yet it is not a steady job; it’s kind of on-call because of the economic situation. To increase his income, he started buying and selling used clothes in the market. Orgit is sole financial provider for his family.

Orgit is requesting a 100,000 ALL loan from Kiva lenders to buy more used clothing to sell. This will be his first loan, and Orgit assures everyone that, based on his responsible character, he will repay his loan on time.

loans.use: to buy second-hand clothing to sell

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip is 42 years old and married with four children, all of whom attend school. He is from Litein town in the south rift in Kenya. For the past 16 years, Philip has been a small-scale farmer, producing tea and milk which he sells at the local market. He also operates a food kiosk in the same town. Philip's business challenges include diseases and insufficient dairy fodder which affect his production. 

Philip is requesting a 55,000 KES loan to construct a green house. His loan will improve his production and increase his income to meet his basic needs. Philip also plans to expand his farming business by acquiring quality dairy cows to increase his milk production and earn him more income.

loans.use: to construct a green house

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 35-year-old married man from Samburu, Kenya. He is the father of two young children. Joseph works buying fruits and vegetables to sell at the market and he works hard to increase his earnings. 

Joseph is requesting a loan to buy more fruits and vegetables such as onions, bananas, tomatoes, and potatoes to sell at the market. He will use his loan to increase his sales and then his profit.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables such as onions, bananas, tomatoes, and potatoes

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en:
This is Milagros. She previously accessed a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan that she used to purchase hogs and feed needed for her business. Her earnings were a big help in her personal, household and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for a new 14,000 PHP loan to buy additional hogs and feeds needed for her business. Her profits from the business will definitely help her to sustain her daily needs. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Milagros hopes that her business will expand, and that she will have more workers that she will manage. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for feeds and more hogs needed in her piggery.

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah is 22 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with one of them currently in school. For the past three years, Aidah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells fast foods. 

To help expand her business, Aidah has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more cassava, Irish potatoes and cooking oil that will be fried for resale and will help Aidah to generate greater profits and pay for food and school fees for her child. 

Aidah hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Aidah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more cassava, irish potatoes and cooking oil to prepare food to sell.

loans.name: Aminah

texts.en:
Aminah is 20 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. 

For the past three years, Aminah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells sugarcane. 

To help expand her business, Aminah has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugarcane for resale and will help Aminah to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. 

Aminah hopes that in the future she will be able to increase her capital and become a rich business woman. 

Aminah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more sugarcane for resale.

loans.name: Maryliza

texts.en:
Maryliza is a 46-year-old married woman and a mother of a 21-year-old son from Ubay, Bohol. She has run a sari-sari (or variety store) business for more than 12 years now. She sells various goods to the people in her community.

Maryliza is asking for a loan to buy more stock to sell in her store, such as canned goods, noodles, chips and biscuits, soda and toiletries. With this, she will be able to attract and cater to more buyers and customers in her store, thus augmenting her sales and profit.

In the future, Maryliza has hopes of expanding her business in order to generate more revenue necessary for the needs of the family.

loans.use: to buy more stock to sell in her store, such as canned goods, noodles, chips and biscuits, soda and toiletries.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 21 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells shoes. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 700000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fashionable shoes to sell, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and pay for her basic needs, like food. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fashionable shoes to sell.

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
This is Marilou, 37, a resident of Payatas, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Onofreg and mother to her children. Together with her husband, Marilou manages her household while operating a variety store. She works hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy a sachet of shampoo, 5-PHP worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Marilou buys supplies at wholesale prices and sells by the piece. Her regular customers are neighbors and local community members and she earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

Marilou is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory and help continue her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands. Marilou dreams of giving her children a good and quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages

loans.name: Nida

texts.en:
This is Nida. She previously received a 16,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase materials for her scrap metal business. The earnings generated with her loan were a big help for her children's education and in her family's personal, household, and business expenditures. 

Nida is requesting a 20,000 PHP loan to incorporate into her revolving fund and purchase more scrap materials. The profit from her loan will definitely help to provide for her daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. Nida looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and she dreams of being able to provide her children with a good and high-quality education through all of her hard work. Nida faithfully meets up weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and draw strength and inspiration from studying the Word of God. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase scrap materials for her business

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine runs a store selling basic necessities such as rice, beans, detergents, flour, etc. She lives with her husband and three children in a house they rent. She has had the business for two months and it is growing little by little.

She is seeking a loan to buy products such as rice, sugar, beans, cleaning products, flour, oil, etc., for the store. The loan will enable her to have more money available to buy stock.

Christine's hope is that her children will be good students and that she will be able to help them with income from the store.

loans.use: to buy products such as rice, sugar, beans, cleaning products, flour, oil, etc., for the store.

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa is a 65-year-old married woman from Bohol, Philippines. 

She has been engaged in a sewing and dressmaking business for more than five years now. This is the source of her income.

Narcisa is asking for a loan to buy more cloth, thread, needles and other materials for sewing. Through this, she will be able to accept more requests from her customers and clients.

Narcisa dreams of making her business a success. Moreover, she wants to save money for reinvestment in the same business and savings for future use.

loans.use: to buy more cloth, thread, needles and other materials for sewing.

loans.name: Prossy's Group

texts.en:
Prossy's group is composed of six hard working women. Prossy is 22 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past four years, Prossy has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells juice. 

To help expand her business, Prossy has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice. It will help Prossy to generate greater profits and buy basic needs for home like food. 

Prossy hopes that in the future she will be able to own a big store that sells sugarcane and to become a big supplier in town. 

Prossy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 46 years old and a dairy farmer from Kitale town in western Kenya. She is married and has five school-age children who all attend school. 

She has been in the farming business for eight years now and solely relies on the income from her farm to meet the needs of her family. She sells her milk to the local market. She faces the challenges of diseases and high cost of dairy feeds, which affect her production.

She has made a loan request of 52,000 KES (Kenyan shillings) through Juhudi Kilimo in order to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable her acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will help her pay school fees for her children and improve the livelihood of her family. 

She plans to increase her milk production by acquiring hybrid dairy cows and also by venturing into poultry farming in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Teofila

texts.en:
Teofila is a 50-year-old married woman and a mother of two children from Bohol, Philippines. 

She earns a living through her variety store, selling various goods and commodities to the people in her community.

Teofila is asking for a loan to buy more stocks to sell such as rice, canned goods, snack foods and chips, soda, soap and toiletries. Through this loan, she will be able to attract more buyers and customers to her store, thus allowing her to augment her sales and profit.

loans.use: to buy more stocks to sell such as rice, canned goods, snack foods and chips, soda, soap and toiletries.

loans.name: Gloria Del Carmen

texts.es: Gloria del Carme de 56 anos de edad, casada con un hijo de 56 anos de la localidad de Chinandega, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona de occidente del país. Chinandega es un lugar que se  caracteriza por ser una zona comercial productiva. Gloria tiene por actividad económica la venta de  refrescos, posicles, chocobananos, venta de cerdos y sus derivados y fritanga. El negocio lo tiene ubicado en su casa de habitación desde hace 10 anos. Gloria se caracteriza por se una mujer muy trabajadora, con ganas  de superación personal. Ya ha trabajado con fundación y ha demostrado su responsabilidad de pago , el financiamiento lo necesita para invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio con la compra de azúcar, frutas, y cerdos para el destace y vender la carne del cerdo y sus derivados como nacatamales, frito, adobando, manteca de cerdo. Gloria agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva le brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
56-year old Gloria del Carme is married and has a son. She lives in Chinandega which is located in the western part of the country. It's known as a productive business area. Gloria earns her living selling soft drinks, popsicles, chocolate-covered bananas etc. She also sells pigs, pork, and fried snacks. Known as a hardworking woman with a desire to get ahead, Gloria has run her business from her home for ten years. 

She has worked with the Foundation in the past and demonstrated responsibility with the loan repayments. The money she needs now is for working capital to buy stock for her store: sugar, fruit, pickling spices, pigs to butcher, meat pasties, fried snacks, lard etc. Gloria is grateful for the help Kiva donors provide to poor people and poor countries like Nicaragua so that people can have work.

loans.use: To buy sugar, fruit, pickling spices, pigs to butcher, meat pasties, fried snacks, lard etc.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David, 46, is married with nine children. Six of the children are currently attending school. He is a small-scale farmer from Kitale county in western Kenya, where he has been farming for fifteen years now. His mixed farm produces maize, vegetables and sugarcane, all of which are sold in the local market. He solely depends on the income from farming to cater to the needs of his family. However, he faces the challenge of diseases that are too expensive to treat and a poor transport network that affects his income.

David has made a loan request of 62,400 KES to purchase and insure a dairy cow. This loan will enable him acquire a quality dairy cow that will produce enough milk for domestic consumption and sale. The proceeds from the sale of milk will enable him improve the livelihood of his family. He hopes that in the near future he will have expanded his farm to five acres and acquired six dairy cows.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia is a 36-year-old married woman and mother of three young children from Bohol, Philippines. She has been engaged in her mat weaving business for more than seven years now. This is the source of her income.

Rosalia works hard to support her husband in meeting the needs of the family, especially for the schooling of her children. Rosalia is asking for a loan to buy coloring and romblon--a tropical plant--and other materials for mat weaving. Through this, she will be able to weave more mats, thus giving her more to sell in the market.

In the future, Rosalia hopes to expand her business so that it will continue to generate more revenue necessary for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy coloring, romblon, and other materials for mat weaving.

loans.name: Tareq

texts.en:
Tareq is a 20-year-old single young man who lives with his family. They live in a quiet area and his father's salary is not enough to cover the family's needs. For the past two years, Tareq has run a small store where he sells clothes. His business has been profitable and he has been able to increase his family's income. Tareq lacks enough capital to cover his costs.

Tareq is requesting a FATEN youth loan to purchase a new collection of clothing to sell. His loan will allow him to provide a greater variety of clothing for his customers to choose and buy. Tareq believes his loan will increase his sales and income. He is photographed inside his store.

loans.use: to purchase a new collection of clothing to sell

loans.name: Stella's Group

texts.en:
Stella's group is comprised of two hardworking women. Stella is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past three years, Stella has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells a variety of goods such as beans, cabbage, nuts and shoes. 

To help expand her business, Stella has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more beans, cabbage, nuts and shoes for resale, and it will help Stella to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Stella hopes that in the future, she will be able to see her business expand into a big shop. 

Stella is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more inventory such as beans, cabbage, nuts and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Boushra

texts.en:
Boushra is from Iraq. She is 49 years old, married and has four children. Her husband and one of her children are employed.

Boushra is a hairdresser who specializes in preparing brides. She has owned a beauty salon since 2005 and now she has two employees. She has a good reputation and she is well known in the surrounding areas.

She is requesting a $3,000 loan to add an extra chair with all its accessories to the shop. She is aiming to grow this business and increase her profits so she will be able to provide her family better life conditions.

loans.use: to add an extra chair with all its accessories to the shop.

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah is a merchant from the rural part of Samburu, Kenya. She earns a living through her retail shop that she operates from her home, serving the community. She has been in this business for the last one year.

Norah is asking for a loan to buy additional stock to sell such as detergents, flour, cooking fat, basic medicines, snacks, drinks, etc. With this loan, she will be able to enhance her stocks, thus allowing her to attract and cater to more customers and buyers in her store. 

In the future, Norah hopes to expand her business and save money for future use and expenses.

loans.use: to buy additional stock to sell such as detergents, flour, cooking fat, basic medicines, snacks, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Nihad

texts.en:
Nihad is from Iraq. He is 37 years old, married and has two children. He is the only provider for the family.

Nihad owns a small shop selling vegetables and fruits. He established his business in 2009. He has a good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a $1,500 loan to renovate the shop. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

loans.use: to renovate the shop.

loans.name: Maria Ines

texts.es: María Inés de 59 anos de edad del departamento de Chinandega, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona de occidente del país. Casada con 6 hijos todos mayores de edad. La actividad económica de  Mari aines de la venta de cerdos desde hace 2 anos. Mari ines es una mujer muy trabajadora, responsable, con ganas de superación personal. El negocio lo tiene ubicado en su casa de habitación, y consisten en comprar lotes de cerdos  para engordar y vender a las personas que tiene negocio de la carne del cerdo. Ella ya ha trabajado con fundación y ha demostrado ser buena pago en tiempo y forma. El objetivo del prestamos es comprar un lote de cerdos y aprovechar la temporada navideña donde  las ventas de incrementa por la diferentes actividades como fin de ano, graduaciones. María Inés agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
María Inés is 59 and lives in Chinandega department, located in the eastern part of the country. She is married and has six adult offspring. For the past two years, María Inés has sold pigs. She is hardworking, responsible, and seeks to get ahead. Her business, which is located on her property, comprises buying pigs in lots to fatten and resell to meat merchants. 

She has worked with the institution and has a good credit history. Her objective for this loan is to purchase a lot of pigs and take advantage of the Christmas season when meat sales are strong for year-end events, graduations, and so forth. María Inés thanks the Kiva lenders for their support of low-income people in poor countries such as Nicaragua that allows them to have decent work.

loans.use: to purchase a group of pigs to fatten and resell.

loans.name: Barbra's Group

texts.en:
Barbra is 22 years old and lives in Seeta town in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, she has been working hard to manage her shoe-selling business. She is a member of a two-person loan group comprised of hardworking women. 

Barbra is requesting a 400,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to buy more fashionable shoes to sell. Her loan will help her generate greater profits to improve her family's standard of living. Barbra hopes that in the future she will be able to own a better shop that sells good shoes. 

Barbra is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy fashionable shoes to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 34 years old and works as a small-scale farmer. She is from Kitale town in western Kenya. Agnes is from the Abaluhya community which is well known for poultry farming and bull fighting. For the past 10 years, she has been running a mixed farm in the Kapenguria division where she produces maize, milk, eggs, and chickens that she sells at the local market. She also operates a retail shop and kiosk where she sells vegetables. 

Agnes is requesting a 31,200 KES loan through Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. She believes that by acquiring a dairy cow her milk production will increase and she will be able to make enough money for her children's upkeep. In the future, Agnes plans to apply for a bigger loan to set up a posho mill.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Besik

texts.en:
Besik is 47 years old. He lives in Martvili District with his wife, son, daughter-in-law and grandchild. The family runs a small dairy farm of two milk cows, whose milk is used in cheese products. The cheese is sold at the local open market. 

Besides dairy farming, Besik serves the local people as a taxi driver with his own car. His wife is involved in a flower-trading business. She purchases flowers locally and sells them in the nearby district for a higher price. 

All of the family members work hard, but the income is not enough for covering the everyday expenses. So, Besik decided to start up a new business. He has requested loans from his local financial institutions several times without any success. His loan requests were rejected every time because of low income and the lack of experience in the new job, which is usually demanded by local credit providers. His loan request was approved under a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo.

The start-up loan program provides startup and re-startup credits with soft conditions for country, rural poor who do not have access to credit products since they are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With the loan, Besik will build a greenhouse. He will purchase building materials and construct it. Besik will plant different kinds of flowers, which will be sold by his wife at a good price. This will increase his income. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva startup loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family. Besik awaits your support.

loans.use: to build a greenhouse to plant flowers that will be sold by his wife.

loans.name: Flavia's Group

texts.en:
Flavia's group is comprised of 2 hard-working women. Flavia is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 2 years, Flavia has been working hard to manage her piggery.

To help expand her business, Flavia has requested a loan from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more pigs to be raised for resale, and will help Flavia to generate greater profits and expand on the rooms for the piggery. Flavia hopes that in the future she will be able to see her business expand into a big farm and become a big supplayer in town.

Flavia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more pigs to be raised for resale,

loans.name: Immaculate

texts.en:
Immaculate is 17 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, she has been working hard to manage her small business where she sells cooked food.

Immaculate is requesting a 600,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to purchase ingredients such as cassava and Irish potatoes. Her loan will help her to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her young siblings. Immaculate hopes that in the future she will be able to improve on her business and become a well-known businesswoman in town. 

Immaculate is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as cassava and Irish potatoes

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 22 years old and lives in the town of Seeta in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past two years, she has been working hard to manage her small business where she sells cooked food. 

Mariam is requesting a 400,000 UGX loan from BRAC Uganda to purchase different types of raw food such as cassava, Irish potatoes, and matooke to cook and sell. Her loan will help her generate greater profits and provide basic needs for her children such as food. Mariam hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Mariam is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients such as cassava, Irish potatoes, and matooke to prepare food

loans.name: Dinora Veneza

texts.es: Dinora de 32 anos de edad, casada con 3 hijos de 14, 12,10 anos, ella es originaria del municipio de Achuapa, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona norte del país. Dinora tiene por actividad económica la una pulpería, ubicada en su casa de habitación. Una pulpería es una pequeña tienda donde se venden productos comestibles en cantidades pequeñas como: cigarros por unidad. Arroz, aceite en ¼, frijoles, pan, leche, huevos, sobrecitos de café, sobre de shampoo. Dinora ha demostrado su responsabilidad de pago  en los créditos anteriores. El objetivo del préstamo es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su pulpería para incrementar sus ventas y mejorar sus ingresos en la compra de productos de consumo diario del hogar. Dinora agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Dinora is 32 years old. She is married and has three children ages 14, 12, and 10. She is a native of the municipality of Achuapa, which is located in the northern part of the country. Dinora runs her own business, a small pulpería, which she runs from her home. A pulpería is a small grocery store where food products are sold in small quantities, such as: individual cigarettes, rice, oil in ¼, beans, bread, milk, eggs, and packets of coffee and shampoo. 

Dinora has shown responsibility by repaying her previous loans. She will use this loan to invest in working capital and to stock her grocery store by buying products of daily consumption for the home in order to increase her sales and improve her income. Dinora is thankful for the help Kiva lenders provide to low income families and poor countries such as Nicaragua so that they too can have decent work.

loans.use: to invest in working capital and to stock her grocery store with products of daily consumption for the home, such as cigarettes, rice, oil in ¼, beans, bread, eggs, and packets of coffee and shampoo.

loans.name: Analisa

texts.en: Analisa is 21 years old and the mother a six-month-old child who lives in Ubay, Bohol. She owns a sari-sari or variety store which she has run for more than two years. She is requesting a loan to buy additional merchandise to sell in her store such as canned goods, snacks, soap and toiletries as well as piglets to raise. In the future, Analisa wants to expand her business and save money to pay for the future schooling of her daughter.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell in her store and piglets to raise.

loans.name: Betty's Group

texts.en: Betty leads a loan group which is made up of two hardworking women. She is 22 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and the mother of two children, both of whom attend school. For the last three years, she has earned a living by selling food. To help expand her business, she is requesting a loan for 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more ingredients such as potatoes, and hopes that increased sales will help her pay for the education of her children. Her goal for the future is to buy a plot of land. Betty is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for a food-making business.

loans.name: G.s. Los Coquitos Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario los Coquitos esta conformado por dos  integrantes Paz Catalina, y Ery . Paz catalina es la coordinadora del grupo solidario la cual se encarga del buen funcionamiento del mismo, ella es originaria del municipio de Somotillo, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona norte del país. Paz  Catalina tiene por actividad económica el servicio de video juegos desde hace 2 anos , ubicado en su casa de habitación. Paz es una mujer responsable, trabajadora, con ganas de superación personal. El objetivo del préstamo es invertir en activo fijos, como la compra de tres  televisores, para darles mejor servicio a sus clientes y de dicha forma obtener mejores ingresos. Paz agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva le brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en: The solidarity group Los Coquitos is comprised of two members, Paz Catalina and Ery. Paz Catalina is the coordinator of the solidarity group and is in charge of the smooth operation for the group. She is originally from Somotillo, a place located in the northern part of the country. Paz Catalina's job for the last two years has been the service of video games, located in her home. Paz is a responsible, hardworking woman who wants to excel. The loan is to invest in fixed assets, such as the purchase of three TVs to give better service to their clients and thereby earn a better income. Paz appreciates the assistance the Kiva investors give to people with limited resources and in poor countries such as Nicaragua, to have a decent work environment.

loans.use: invest in fixed assets in working capital to purchase three televisions for video game service.

loans.name: Veronica De Los Angeles

texts.es: Verónica de 38 anos de edad, casada con cuatro hijos menores de edad de 13, 10, 8, 3, anos todos está estudiando. Ella es originaria del municipio de Malpaisillo, lugar que esta ubicado en la zona de occidente del país. Ella tiene por actividad económica nintendo y fritanga. El negocio surgió por la necesidad de tener una fuente de trabajo y ayudar con los gastos del hogar. Verónica ha demostrado su responsabilidad de pago en tiempo y forma en los créditos anteriores. El financiamiento lo necesita para invertir en capital de trabajo y darles mantenimiento a los equipos. Verónica agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener fuentes de trabajo digna.
texts.en:
Verónica is 38 years old, married, and has four minor children, ages 13, 10, 8 and 3, who are all in school. She is from the town of Malpaisillo, located in the western part of the country. Her work is renting Nintendo games and preparing Nicaraguan fast food.

The business came about because of her need to have a source of work and help with the household expenses. Veronica has shown herself to be responsible, by paying back the previous loans in a timely manner.

She needs loan in order to have working capital and to maintain her equipment. Veronica is thankful for the help that the Kiva investors offer to low-income people and to poor countries such as Nicaragua, so that people can have decent livelihoods.

loans.use: To have working capital and maintain her equipment.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is 22 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past three years, she has been working hard to manage her restaurant, where she earns a living by selling cooked food. To help expand her business, she is requesting a loan for 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more food, including plantain, rice and beans as well as chairs and some tables. She hopes that these items will help her earn a larger income, which will allow her to pay for her child's education. Her goal for the future is to expand her business into a big hotel. Jackline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to making microfinance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more food for a restaurant as well as additional chairs and tables.

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en:
Gorret is 23 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past year, Gorret has been working hard to manage her small clothing business. 

To help expand her business, Gorret has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more new fashionable clothes for resale, and will help Gorret to generate greater profits and add to the business so it can expand. Gorret hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand her business into a big shop. 

Gorret is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to stock more new fashionable clothes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and commercial maize and sorghum seed

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Madame Awa est une femme mariée qui vit au Sénégal.  Elle s’active dans le secteur du commerce de l’habillement depuis plus de 5 ans.  Elle pratique la vente de vêtements.  Les revenus  que lui procure son activité lui permettent d’agrandir son commence et supporter les charges quotidiennes de sa famille.  Elle sollicite un crédit de 150,000 frs prévu pour l’achat de vêtements qu’elle va revendre.  Son objectif est d’augmenter le niveau de ses bénéfices, son vœu dans le futur est d’acquérir un grand magasin de vente de vêtements.
texts.en:
Awa is a married woman who lives in Senegal. She has been active in the clothing trade for over five years. Her business is in clothing sales. The income Awa earns from her clothing sales enables her to expand her business, and to pay for the daily needs of her family.

She is requesting a loan of 150,000 XOF which she will use to purchase the clothing she will then resell. Her aim is to increase the income she earns, and she hopes to someday acquire a department store where she can sell her clothing.

loans.use: to purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Racheal is 21 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past year, Racheal has been working hard to manage her shop that sells medicine. 

To help expand her business, Racheal has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock different medicines and other items for the clinic, and will help Racheal generate greater profits and register her drug shop with the authorities. Racheal hopes that in the future she will be able to save her money to open up a clinic. 

Racheal is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to stock different medicines and other items for the clinic.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and commercial maize and sorghum seed

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Pedro es de la comarca Asedades, en las afuera de Teustepe, casado, tiene dos hijos  mayores de edad. El  se dedica ala venta de reloj, fajas, cartera, desde hace 8 años, anteriormente trabajaba como  electricista en el mercado, el siempre estuvo ahorrando. Pero al que dar sin trabajo no sabia que hacer, un amigo muy cercano le sugirió que se fueran juntos a vender  mercadería  a otra ciudad, poco apoco fue multiplicando el dinero que tenia. Actualmente uno de su hijo le ayuda a atender el negocio.

Pedro hoy esta solicitando este crédito para comprar reloj, fajas carteras y calculadoras para la venta, y   reforzar mas el negocio, asi poder mejorar  sus ingresos, de igual manera mejorar la infraestructura de su casa.
texts.en:
Pedro is from the county Asedades, on the outskirts of Teustepe.  He is married with two adult children. Pedro has been selling watches, belts, purses for 8 years.  He previously worked as an electrician in the market, and he was always saving. But upon being unemployed he didn't know what to do, so a very close friend suggested that they go together to sell merchandise to another city.  His money gradually increased. Currently, one of his children helps him tend to the business.

Today, Pedro is requesting this loan to buy watches, belts, wallets and calculators to sell.  He also wants to further strengthen the business to increase his income in order to improve the infrastructure of his home.

loans.use: to buy watches, belts, wallets and calculators to sell.

loans.name: Yannick

texts.fr:
Yannick est un jeune camerounais âgé de 25 ans qui mène comme activité la vente des vêtements et ces chapeaux dans un quartier de la ville depuis 01 an environ.il s'approvisionne à Douala en détails auprès des revendeurs. il voudrait ainsi avec ce crédit acheter un ballot de jeans non seulement pour renforcer son stock de marchandises, mais aussi pour accroître son portefeuille clientèle car les détaillants pourront également s'approvisionner auprès de lui.
il a comme ambition pour son activité d'ouvrir un grand prêt à porter
texts.en:
Yannick is a young Cameroonian of 25 years old. He runs a business selling clothes and hats in a district of the city, where he has been working for the past year. He buys his merchandise in Douala at retail from sellers there.

Yannick wants to use this loan to buy a bundle of jeans. This will not only expand his stock of goods, but will also increase his client portfolio as retailers will be able to buy their supplies from him. Yannick's ambition is to open his own shop selling ready to wear clothing.

loans.use: to purchase a bundle of jeans for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, commercial maize, and sorghum seed

loans.name: Raed

texts.en:
Raed is a 38-year-old single man. He is employed in a local company and gets a low salary, which is not enough to cover his needs. For the past two years, Raed has had a grocery store selling different types of groceries. It has been a profitable project, but more financial support is needed to cover the costs.
Raed is requesting a USD 1,500 loan from FATEN to help him cover the costs of purchasing needed stock of basic groceries that customers often request such as rice, sugar, and dairy products. This will increase sales and increase Raed's income.
Raed is photographed inside his store.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell

loans.name: Veronicah

texts.en:
Veronicah is a 42-year-old farmer in Kitale county in Kenya, where she lives with her husband and four children who are all in school. She has been in farming for the past 15 years producing horticultural crops, milk, and poultry products which she sells at the local market.
She is requesting a 70,000 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry birds to sell poultry products and earn extra income that will boost her livelihood and help her pay for her children's education. She aspires to expand her dairy and poultry projects and double her production in the next five years.
High costs of farm inputs, inadequate capital, and unreliable rainfall are her major challenges in farming.
Veronicah is grateful to Juhudi Kilimo for the great support to farmers.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy additional stock of second hand clothing

loans.name: Twitezimbere Bahinzi /kzr Group

texts.fr:
Emmanuel est l’agriculteur du riz. Il fait partie du groupe solidaire appelé TWITEZIMBERE BAHINZI /KZR. Il est marié et a 35 ans. Il a 4 enfants dont le plus âgé a 12 ans et le moins âgé a 9 ans. Deux de ses enfants vont à l’école. Il n’a aucune autre personne en sa charge. Il est né au Rwanda et a 5 ans de l’école primaire.
Il a commencé de collaborer avec ACB Ltd en 2012 et il est au deuxième cycle crédit. Le premier crédit est remboursé sans retard.
Avec le présent crédit, il va acheter 80 kilos des engrais chimiques et la partie restant paiera la main d’œuvre. 
N’attendant aucune difficulté de non remboursement, Monsieur Emmanuel envisage la stratégie de cultiver à temps en utilisant les bonnes semences. Ceci accroitra son activité agricole.
Son ambition est de devenir le grand cultivateur du riz dans la région. Pour sa famille, il va éduquer les enfants jusqu’au niveau universitaire.
texts.en:
Emmanuel is a rice farmer. He belongs to the joint-liability association called Twitezimbere Bahinzi /kzr Group. He is married and is 35 years old. Emmanuel has four children, the eldest of whom is 12 years old and the youngest of whom is nine. Two of his children currently attend school. He has no additional dependents other than his four children. He was born in Rwanda and has had five years of primary education.

Emmanuel began working with ACB Ltd in 2012 and is on his second loan cycle. His first loan has been fully repaid. With his present loan, Emmanuel plans to purchase 80 kilos of chemical fertilizers, and to pay for the labor required to work his rice field. As he does not expect to have any problems with repayment, Emmanuel's planning strategy is to cultivate in a timely manner, and to use good quality seeds. This will maximize his agricultural yields. His ambition is to become the largest rice grower in the region. For his family, Emmanuel plans to educate his children to the university level.

loans.use: to purchase 80 kilos of chemical fertilizers, and to pay for the labor required to work his rice field.

loans.name: Rosa  Amada

texts.es:
Rosa es una mujer de 57 años, cursó los estudios primarios y se casó muy joven, se separó de su esposo hace poco tiempo y ha sido una situación muy difícil para ella, pero decidió seguir llevando a cabo su vida con más empeño y fuerza de voluntad Vive en el cantón Pastaza ubicado en la Provincia con el mismo nombre, perteneciente a la Región Amazónica de la República del Ecuador. La cabecera cantonal es la ciudad del Puyo una ciudad ubicada en medio de la selva amazónica al occidente de la provincia de Pastaza y a 924 m. sobre el nivel del mar. Es demográficamente pequeña pero tiene una gran variedad de sitios que son los preferidos para turistas nacionales e internacionales sobre todo los de actividades ecológicas y de deportes extremos. Una ciudad que crece económicamente cada día por las actividades de comercio, ganadería, agricultura y turismo, por lo que en ella se han establecido sucursales de empresas financieras y comerciales que pretenden aprovechar la actividad económica que mantiene esta ciudad. La competencia entre microempresarios es muy grande, sin embargo cada uno ha puesto su valor agregado para ganar preferencia con los clientes. 
Rosa tras su separación, se encontraba insegura sobre su futuro, allí en Pastaza, sola sintió que no había alternativa para ella por su avanzada edad. Sin embargo las limitaciones duraron poco cuando puso en práctica los conocimientos impartidos por sus padres en emprendimiento y comercio de especias para los alimentos. Desde que sale el sol, Rosa abre las puertas de su negocio ubicado en un pequeño espacio del mercado del pueblo, el cual comenzó desde hace 10 años con la ayuda y apoyo de su hija. Rosa se ha convertido en una mujer emprendedora y piensa que siempre se puede alcanzar más y que nunca es tarde para soñar. Con 10 horas al día que invierte en esta actividad se ha dado cuenta que su negocio puede crecer de alguna forma. Es por eso que se decidió a solicitar un préstamo para comprar especias y hierbas para incrementar sus ventas. Fundación Alternativa otorgó este crédito y además ha ofrecido a Rosa la capacitación y asesoría necesarias para administrar de forma correcta sus recursos tangibles e intangibles. Rosa agradece a los prestamistas de Kiva por aportar su granito de arena al cumplimiento de su sueño de ser una microempresaria exitosa.
texts.en:
Rosa, 57, went to elementary school, and then married young. She recently separated from her husband, which has been a very difficult situation for her, but she decided to keep moving forward with more determination and strength of will. She lives in the canton of Pastaza, in the provine of the same name, which is part of the Amazonian region of Ecuador. The capital of the canton is the city of Puyo, which is located in the middle of the Amazon rainforest, just west of the province of Pastaza at 924 metres above sea level. Demographically it’s a small area, but it has a variety of sites that attract national and international tourists, especially ecological endeavours and extreme sports.
It’s a city that grows economically every day because of commerce, livestock breeding, agriculture and tourism; for this reason, financial and commercial businesses have opened branches here to take advantage of the economic activity maintining the city. Competition between companies is strong, but each has promoted its own added value to gain preference with clients. 
After her separation, Rosa found herself insecure about her future; there in Pastaza she felt that she had no alternatives because of her advanced years. However, those limitations didn’t last long when she put into practise the knowledge she gained from her parents, concering the undertaking of a business and selling spices.
After the sun comes out, Rosa opens the doors to her business, which is located in a small space in the local market. She started her business 10 years ago with the help and support of her daughter. Rosa has become a determined woman and thinks one can always accomplish more and it’s never too late to dream. With the 10 hours that she invests in her work every day, she knows her business can grow in some way. That’s why she decided to request a loan to buy spices and herbs in order to increase her sales. “Fundación Alternativa” communal bank has offered Rosa the training and advice to correctly administrate her tangible and intangible resources. Rosa is grateful to the Kiva lenders for contributing their grain of sand to the accomplishment of her dream of being a successful small business.

loans.use: buy spices and ingredients to stock her business.

loans.name: Madona

texts.en:
Madona is 36 years old, married and lives in Batumi city with her husband and two children (12 and 15 years old). The children go to the local school and her husband is an armament officer who earns a monthly salary. Madona’s economic activity is a newly started small grocery store. She also rents out a room in her house to earn additional monthly income. Madona requested a loan from local financial institutions for the business expansion, but without success. Her loan request was rejected because of low income and insufficient experience in her business.
Her loan request was approved through a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The program provides start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. They do not have access to traditional credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income.

Madona requested a loan to equip the store with an additional refrigerator. She will keep perishable products there and will be able to sell meat which is in high demand. The existing refrigerators are inadequate to store all the inventory. When Madona has an additional refrigerator, she will be able to increase her inventories as well as the turnover in the store. This will raise the income of the family, which will be used to improve the family’s living conditions. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator for her grocery store.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 22 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Eva has been working hard to manage her salon, which does hair styling. 

To help expand her business, Eva has requested a loan of 600000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more hair styling products and equipment, including a big dryer. This will help Eva generate greater profits and save some money for her child's school fees. Eva hopes that in the future she will be able to develop her business more. 

Eva is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more hair styling products and equipment, including a big dryer, for her salon.

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Madame Adama est une femme mariée qui vit au Sénégal.  Elle capitalise une expérience de plus de 7 ans dans le secteur du commerce et pratique la vente de bijoux. Les revenus tirés de son activité lui permettent de soutenir ses 5 enfants agés entre 4 et 19 ans. Elle envisage d’augmenter son fond de commerce parle biais du prêt de 100 000 qu’il sollicite au niveau du guichet de l’UIMCEC ou elle est membre. L’objet du crédit consiste a s’approvisionner en bijoux qu’elle compte revendre a sa clientèle. Sou souhait est de devenir une grande commerçante de bijoux dans le futur.
texts.en:
Adama is a married woman who lives in Senegal. She has had over seven years of experience as a merchant, and runs her business selling jewelry. The income she earns from her business allow her to support her five children, aged between four and 19 years old.

Adama is seeking a 100,000 XOF loan from the local UIMCEC office where she is a member. She plans to use this loan to expand her business. Adama will use her loan to purchase a supply of jewelry that she will resell to her customers. Her hope to someday become a major jewelry retailer.

loans.use: to purchase jewelry for resale.

loans.name: Jansughi

texts.en:
Jansughi is 49 years old and lives with his wife and two children (15 and 18 years old) in Zestaponi district. The only source of income for the family is the small income, earned by Jansughi, who is involved in book trading. He has been running the business during five years and the project was profitable, but now it needs financial support. Several times, he has asked for loans from local financial institutions to develop his business with no success. His loan requests were rejected each time because of his low income.
Jansughi’s loan request was approved as part of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program provides business start-ups and re-startups with credit, with soft conditions to the rural poor who do not have access to credit products, since they are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. With the received credit, Jansughi will cover the costs of purchasing needed stock of books that customers often request. He plans to increase the turnover in his trade business gradually. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly increase the income of the family. Jansughi will work hard, and he will be able to improve the living conditions for his family. With this loan, the family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market, in the event it is needed.

loans.use: to purchase books for resale

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en:
Cissy is 23 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past two years, Cissy has been working hard to manage her small business selling vegetables. 
To help expand her business, Cissy has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more vegetables, such as green cabbage, for resale, and it will help Cissy to generate greater profits and add in the business to expand. Cissy hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 
Cissy is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables such as green cabbage for resale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is a petty trader. She sells dresses and underwear for ladies and children at Amkwamda near Elmina. She has been in this business for the past two years now. Comfort is married. She uses her income to help her husband pay the utility and accommodation bills.  She needs this loan to enable her  to purchase more underwear and ladies' and children's dresses to sell. With the new profit, she plans to acquire a shop for the sale of her dresses.

loans.use: to purchase more underwear, and ladies' and children's dresses to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and commercial maize and sorghum seed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchase maize in bulk to produce kenkey for distribution.

loans.name: Titus

texts.en:
Titus still practices mixed farming, which he has done for the past four years and the business has improved very much. He used his previous loan to buy farm inputs and potato seedlings and he got a very good harvest.


Now he has applied for his second loan from KADET LTD, to enable him pay labor costs and to buy fertilizer and potato seeds for planting. He will plow the anticipated profit back into his business, to grow crops and buy more dairy cows for milk production.

He hopes to improve his standards of living and provide for his family all the basic needs in the near future.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, potato seeds and to pay labor.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cereals to sell.

loans.name: Christoper

texts.en:
Christoper is a 36-year-old married man. He has 2 children. He describes himself as a determined man. 

Christoper operates a retail store where he sells clothes. He has been involved in this business for 7 years. His business is located in a suitable business environment and his primary customers are local residents. He describes his biggest business challenge as insufficient funds for improving the business. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to buy clothes to sell during the December holiday. His business goal is to improve his business within 5 years. He hopes that in the future, he will educate his children with the profits generated. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Annah

texts.en:
Annah is a 36-year-old married woman. She has a child who is 13 years old. She describes herself to be honest woman. 

She operates a grocery store where she sells vegetables and fruits. She has been involved in this business for 4 years. Her business is located within a productive area and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business.

She will use the loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to buy vegetables and fruits to sell. Her business goal is to improve her business within 5 years. This is her first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua cooks banku for sale. She serves it with fried fish, pepper, and tomato sauce at Abura. She is married and has four dependents. Efua has been in this business for four years now. She uses her income to support her husband in the general upkeep of their children. Her loan will be used to purchase bags of maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku for sale. She hopes to use the new profit from her expanded business to mount a better stall for the sale of her banku.

loans.use: to purchase bags of maize and fish which she uses in preparing her banku for sale

loans.name: Maura

texts.es:
Maura catalogada por su familia como la mas alegre y optimista, tiene 30 años y conforma una familia a lado de sus 2 hijos y pareja. Gracias al precio de muchos años de esfuerzo y trabajo logró concretar el primer piso de su vivienda a base de concreto y ladrillos. Viene desarrollando el cultivo y mantenimiento de cacao desde hace 8 años gracias a unas parcelas que recibió en calidad de herencia por parte de sus padres, fue así como la necesidad de mantener a su primer hijo le brinda esta gran oportunidad convirtiéndose hoy en una gran productora de cacao de su localidad.
Para el normal desempeño de sus actividades siempre cuenta con personal externo o jornaleros quienes apoyan en todas las actividades necesarias debido a que la dimensión de sus parcelas son de un tamaño considerable y requiere participación colectiva.
Le agrada mucho su trabajo debido a que considera que la labor en el campo como la mas reconfortante y sana que existe, aunque lo complicado es realizar el deshierbo de las plantas ya que considera toma mucho tiempo y  requiere de un esfuerzo singular. A pesar de ello cataloga  muy rentable su producción por hallarse en una zona donde el cacao obtiene una calidad única.
Ella desea iniciar la campaña de cacao de una manera distinta, planea reemplazar los árboles de cacao antiguos y usar los tallos restantes para aplicar la técnica de injerto para el cual es necesario invertir en la compra de plantas de almácigo, abono orgánico, herramientas y personal capacitado para un óptimo resultado, de esta manera sacarle el máximo provecho a sus parcelas esperando así se incrementen sus ingresos al final de la campaña.
Desea a futuro iniciar un negocio propio paralelo a su trabajo en el campo con la apertura de una tienda de abarrotes por considerarlo una buena alternativa cuando no se requiere su presencia en las actividades productivas y la época de lluvia. Este es su tercer crédito con MFP, se siente muy agradecida por la oportunidad que le brindan ya que gracias a ello puede desarrollar sus actividades productivas con total fluidez y confianza. Se siente muy confiada y motivada por como los integrantes de su banco comunal se sienten comprometidos con el pago responsable de sus créditos.
Con los 1,000 nuevos soles complementará su capital destinado para la compra inmediata de plantas de almácigo para injertos, abono orgánico y el pago anticipado a los jornaleros quienes realizarán todas las tareas necesarias.
texts.en:
Maura is known to her family as being the happiest and most optimistic person.  She’s 30 years old and her family includes her husband and two children.  Thanks to her many years of hard work she was able to build the first floor of her house out of concrete and brick.  She has been developing and maintaining her cacao plantation for the past 8 years, thanks to some parcels of farmland that she inherited from her parents.  The need to support her son created this opportunity and she has been able to become a great cacao producer in her area.

She can always count on external personnel or helpers for her normal activities, since her parcel of land is large and requires outside help.

She likes her job very much because she considers the work in the fields the healthiest there is, even though cultivating the plants takes a lot of time and effort.  Despite that, she considers her production to be very profitable because she is located in a zone where the cacao is of a unique quality.

She wants to begin the cacao campaign in a different way.  She plans to replace the old trees and use the leftover stems to graft, so she needs to buy new plants, fertilizer, tools and hire trained people in order to get an optimal result and get the maximum benefit from her parcels.  In this way she hopes to increase her income by the end of the campaign.

In the future she wants so start her own parallel business by adding a grocery store that she can run whenever she does not have to work the fields during the rainy season.  This will be her third loan thorough MFP and she is very grateful for the opportunity given because it allows her to develop her productive activities with complete fluidity and confidence.  She feels very confident and motivated by how the members of her communal bank feel responsible for making their loan payments. 

She will use the 1,000 PEN to supplement her working capital to use toward her immediate purchase of nursery plants for grafting, compost, and to pay for necessary laborers who will do the work.

loans.use: to buy plants and pay for labor.

loans.name: Rufina

texts.es:
De 46 años, Rufina se encuentra casada con su compañero de toda la vida Máximo, para complemento de su alegría familiar tiene a sus 4 hijos: Vanesa, Frank, Romario y Luis.
Se dedica a la actividad productiva de cacao, barbasco y maíz desde hace 25 años, con la basta experiencia de toda una vida siempre tuvo el firme apoyo de Máximo con quien ha logrado brindarle a sus menores hijos todo lo necesario para forjarles un futuro provechoso.
El barbasco es uno de los productos cuya presencia llega a ocupar gran parte de su parcela pues es usado después de un proceso industrial como insecticida natural, motivo por el cual tiene un alto precio en el mercado externo, es por ello que dedica gran parte de su tiempo en el mantenimiento de las plantas que crecen como raíces. No obstante para ello debe de realizar una inversión considerable en cuanto a mano de obra se refiere.
Pasado 5 meses de la última cosecha desea nuevamente realizar plantaciones para el cual debe contar con un promedio de 10 jornaleros quienes deben de realizar una ardua limpieza del área a cultivarse así como la siembra de las raíces, adicional a ello brindarle la debida atención y deshierbo a sus plantaciones de cacao para tener un soporte económico adicional. Por tanto desea solicitar 
1,000 mil nuevos soles para contratar jornaleros para la limpieza de terreno destinado para la futura producción de barbasco y mantenimiento de sus plantaciones de cacao.
texts.en:
Rufina, 46, is married to her life companion, Máximo, and to add to their family joy they have four children: Vanesa, Frank, Romario and Luis.  She has worked growing cocoa beans, ‘barbasco’ [an evergreen bush] and corn for 25 years.  With the vast experience she’s gained throughout her life and with the firm support she’s always had from Máximo, she’s managed to provide her minor children with everything necessary to forge a profitable future for them.

Barbasco is one of the products that can take up a large portion of her parcel because it’s used later in an industrial process as a natural insecticide which is why it has a high market price in the foreign markets and why she spends a great part of her time caring for the plants that grow from roots.  Even though, she still has to make a considerable investment in manpower.

Five months after the last harvest, she wants to once again plant and to do so needs to hire on average ten day laborers who will do the hard work of clearing the fields to ready them for planting as well as planting the roots.  In addition to this, proper maintenance and weeding of the cocoa bean plants must also be done in order to have additional economic support.  Because of this she’d like to request 1,000 new soles to hire day laborers to clear the field earmarked for future barbasco production and to provide cocoa bean crop maintenance.

loans.use: to hire day laborers.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi sells beads and jewelry at Ankwanda near Elmina. 

Esi has been through senior high school.  She is married with five children.  She has been in this trade for five years. She assists her husband in the upkeep of their home. 

Her loan will be used to buy additional beads and jewelry to sell. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional beads and jewelry to sell.

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas wants a Fresh Life Toilet for several reasons. He manages a primary school in Mukuru and needs a toilet for the school pupils. Additionally, he wishes to provide sanitation services to families living in close proximity to the school. This way, the Fresh Life Toilet, a sanitation system that collects waste cleanly and converts it into high-value byproducts, will benefit both the school and the local community.

The school Douglas currently runs is in Riara, a sub area of the Kwa Njenga informal settlements of Nairobi. The school has both a kindergarten section and a primary section.

In the future, Douglas foresees a community that is clean, safe and healthy, where the local community is empowered and able to make lifelong positive community impacts in the informal settlements.

loans.use: To purchase and run one Fresh Life Toilet

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia, 46, is a university graduate. She lives in the community of Congo Town called Chugbor. She is a widow, and the mother of two children who are between the ages of 9 and 15, and are currently in school. She started with the initial capital of 8,000 Liberia dollars, which she received from her brother. She has sold salt, pepper, onion, palm oil, vita, rice and black pepper for the past fifteen years. She likes this type of business because she makes a profit. With the profit she buys more goods and attends to the needs of her children.

She has requested this loan to purchase more rice, vita, onion, pepper and cooking oil for the business. Her plan is to become an international business woman.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, vita, onion, pepper, and cooking oil for the business

loans.name: Rafaela Emilia

texts.es: Rafaela Emilia de  28 anos de edad, madre soltera con un hijo de 10 anos de edad. Del municipio de Malpaisillo. Lugar que esta ubicado en la zona norte del país. Rafaela tiene por actividad económica la venta de mercadería en general que consisten en la venta de  ropa, de hombre, de niño, pantalones, faldas, vestidos, blusas, ropa interior, zapatos. El negocio lo tiene ubicado de forma ambulante y surgió con el objetivo de tener una fuente de ingreso para ayudar con los gastos del hogar. El objetivo del préstamo es para invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio en la compra y venta de productos como camisas, faldas, vestidos, ropa interior, pantalones.  Rafaela Emilia agradece la ayuda que los inversionistas kiva les brindan a personas de escasos recursos y países pobre como es Nicaragua para tener un medio de trabajo digno.
texts.en:
Rafaela Emilia is 28 years old. She is a single mother to a 10-year-old son. She is from the municipality of Malpaisillo, located in the northern part of the country.
Rafaela's business is the selling of merchandise such as men's and children's clothing, trousers, skirts, dresses, blouses, underwear and shoes. 
The business is a street trade that originated with the goal of having an income source to help with the household expenses.
The aim of this loan is to invest in working capital and supply her business with shirts, skirts, dresses, underwear and trousers. Rafaela Emilia is grateful for the help Kiva lenders provide to low income people from poor countries such as Nicaragua that allows them to get a decent work.

loans.use: to invest in her clothing business and supply it with merchandise such as trousers, skirts, dresses, underwear, blouses.

loans.name: Silvio Jose

texts.es:
Silvio habitantes es de las Comarcas las  Bandera, Teustepe,  casado, el es padre de 3 hijos de los cuales solo uno tiene a su cargo. Se dedica a la compra y venta de piedra cantera, esta actividad la realiza por medio de un camión, que se lo financio un amigo hace 4 años, y que poco a poco se lo fue cancelando. Actualmente el camión ya es propio. El dice que todos los días por la tarde visita su iglesia evangélica, agradeciendo al señor por todo el progreso que ha tenido hasta hoy. El  atraves de su camión le da trabajo a dos personas que le ayudan a cargar y vender las piedras cantera.

Silvio solicita este crédito para comprar mas piedra cantera, para irla almacenando y vender a varias comunidades, este tipo de piedra se utiliza para la construcción de casas.  Para tener en inventario  ya que en esta época navideña aumenta la demanda de su producto , sus meta próxima  es poder pagar este crédito y volver a solicitar otro para comprar otro camión usado para que lo trabaje su hijo.
texts.en:
Silvio lives in the Las Banderas district of Teustepe.  He's married and the father of three children, only one of whom is in his care.  He makes a living buying and selling quarry stone.  He does his job with a truck that a friend financed for him four years ago.  He repaid the debt little by little, and now the truck belongs to him.  He says that every afternoon he visits his evangelical church, thanking the Lord for all his progress thus far.  With his truck he gives work to two people who help him carry and sell the quarry stone.
