Kosay is from Iraq. He is 29 years old, married and has one child. Kosay is the only provider of the family.

Kosay owns a small restaurant/café. He established his business in 2003 and now he has two employees. He has built a good experience in this field and he is well known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

He is requesting a loan of $2,000 to paint his restaurant/café and to install a new floor. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family better life conditions.

loans.use: to paint his restaurant/café and to install a new floor.

loans.name: Jamiila

texts.en:
Jamiila is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past year, Jamiila has been working hard to manage her small food stall, which sells raw food. 

To help expand her business, Jamiila has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food such as matooke (steamed green bananas) and sweet potatoes for resale. It will help Jamiila to generate greater profits and take care of herself and buy basic needs for the family. Jamiila hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger business than what she has now. 

Jamiila is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more food such as matooke and sweet potatoes for sale in her food stall.

loans.name: Allen's Group

texts.en:
Allen's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Allen is 17 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past two years, Allen has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells all types of flour, sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Allen has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more essential commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap for resale, and will help Allen to generate greater profits, which will be used to buy food at home. Allen hopes that in the future she will be able to earn more, which will help take care of her family. 

Allen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more essential commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and commercial maize and sorghum seed.

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, Nadia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells all types of flour, sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Nadia has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap. This will help Nadia to generate greater profits and expand her business into a bigger shop and to buy more items for the shop, which will increase her capital. Nadia hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land. 

Nadia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more commodities like milk, bread, sugar and soap for her store.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past three years, Jane has been working hard to manage her small business, which sells soft drinks. 

To help expand her business, Jane has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice that will be sold. This will help Jane to generate greater profits and buy basic needs at home like food. Jane hopes that in the future she will be able to own a bigger business. 

Jane is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.


"

loans.use: to buy more fruits that will be used for making juice that will be sold.

loans.name: Ismaeil

texts.en:
Ismaeil is from Iraq. He is 46 years old, married and has four children. Ismaeil is the only provider of the family. He owns a small grocery store selling soft drinks, juices, cheese, dairy products, detergents and snacks. He established his business in 2006. He is well known in the surrounding area and has an excellent reputation.

He is requesting an $1,800 loan to install a new floor in his mini-market and to increase his inventory. He is aiming to grow his business and increase his profits so he will be able to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to install a new floor in his mini-market and to increase his inventory.

loans.name: Hadijja

texts.en:
Hadijja is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has two children with one of them currently in school. For the past year, Hadijja has been working hard to manage her small food stall, which sells fruits. 

To help expand her business, Hadijja has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fruits like tomatoes and will help Hadijja to generate greater profits and buy basic needs at home like food. Hadijja hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a bigger food stall. 

Hadijja is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fruits like tomatoes for resale

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 47 years old. She lives with her husband and two children in Khelvachauri District, West Georgia. Her husband works as an artisan locally and gets a monthly income. Her economic activity is a newly started business. In particular, a grocery store. 

Eva requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for further developing her business, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of lack of experience in her business, which is usually demanded by local credit providers.
  
Her loan request was approved within the frames of new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to country rural poor, who do not have access to credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. 

With the received credit, Eva will cover the costs of purchasing her stock of basic groceries for starting a grocery store. She plans to work hard and increase the turnover in her business gradually. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family. 

With this loan, her family will generate enough income to access regular available credit products in the country’s capital market, in the event they need it.

loans.use: to purchase stock of basic groceries for starting a grocery store.

loans.name: Aby

texts.fr: Madame Aby est une femme mariée qui vit dans une localité sénégalaise, elle est mère de 9 enfants. Elle évolue depuis plus de six ans dans le secteur du commerce et exerce la vente de tissus et sacs. Elle est membre d’un guichet de l’UIMCEC et sollicite un crédit de 300 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de tissus et sacs destinés a la vente. Elle souhaite aussi diversifier les produits qu’elle commercialise en intégrant d’autres articles pour femmes. Son objectif est d’accroitre ses bénéfices pour pouvoir mieux assister sa famille et satisfaire ses besoins personnels. Son vœu est de disposer d’un grand magasin de vente de tissus, d’écharpes, de sacs.
texts.en:
Aby is a married woman who lives in a town in Senegal. She has nine children.

Aby shifted into the retail sector over six years ago. She sells fabric and bags. She is a member of a branch of the UIMCEC, and she is seeking a 300,000 frs loan in order to buy fabric and bags to resell. She also wants to diversify the products that she sells by incorporating other feminine items.

Her objective is to increase her profits so that she can better care for her family and cover her own personal needs. Her dream is to have a big store where she can sell fabric, scarfs, and bags.

loans.use: to buy fabric, bags, and other feminine items for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase 70kg of chemical fertilizer and pay labourers

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 32 years old and married with one child.

She earns a living by raising livestock in the Philippines. Gina has been raising livestock for two years and also earns additional income from buying and selling coconut wine.

Gina is borrowing PHP 11,500 through NWTF to buy additional livestock to raise. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional livestock to raise.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.fr: Mercy est une femme célibataire qui vit dans un quartier de la capitale. Mère d'un enfant, elle gère un salon de coiffure dont elle est propriétaire. Grace à la maîtrise de son activité  et à son dynamisme, elle s'est faite une grande clientèle dont elle aimerait continuer d'assurer la satisfaction. Pour cela elle sollicite ce crédit pour acheter des produits de beauté. Les bénéfices tirés de ce prêt lui permettront d'augmenter son capital et de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mercy is single and lives in a neighbourhood of the capital. She has one child. 

Mercy manages a hairdressing salon that she owns. Thanks to her excellent business skills and dynamism, she has built up a large clientele, which she would like to continue to serve well. In order to do this, she has requested this loan to purchase beauty products. The profits made using this loan will enable her to increase her capital and meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: to purchase beauty products.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase chemical fertilizers and pay labourers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes ahead of the Christmas season when demand is high.

loans.name: Irene's Group

texts.en:
Irene's group is composed of three hardworking women. Irene is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past four years, Irene has been working hard to manage her small restaurant business, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more food that will be cooked for resale. This will help Irene to generate greater profits and increase her capital to buy needed items for the restaurant. Irene hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own. 

Irene is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more food that will be cooked for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase 60kgs of chemical fertilizer and pay labourers.

loans.name: Dusangirimirimo Group

texts.fr:
Monsieur Philemon est membre du groupe solidaire DUSANGIRIMIRIMO.  Son activité principale est l’agriculture du riz. La dite activité est celle qui est financée. A part de l’activité financée, il fait aussi le petit commerce.
Agé de 46 ans, il est marié et a 6 enfants dont le plus âgé a 20 ans et le moins âgé a 3 ans. Cinq de ses enfants vont à l’école et aucune autre personne n’est en sa charge.
Il est né au Rwanda et son niveau d’éducation est 8 ans de l’école primaire.
Il a débuté de collaborer avec ACB Ltd depuis 2011 et actuellement est au 3ème cycle de crédit. Les deux premiers cycles sont bien remboursés.
Avec le crédit sollicité, il va acheter 40 kilos d’engrais chimiques et paiera la main d’œuvre avec la partie qui reste. 
N’envisageant aucune difficulté de non remboursement de ce prêt, Monsieur Philemon va travailler avec toute sa force pour accroitre son activité agricole.  Il a l’ambition d’être le grand cultivateur du riz dans toute la région. Pour sa famille, il va éduquer ses enfants et les fera soigner.
texts.en:
Philemon is a member of the Dusangirimirimo solidarity group. His main business is rice farming, and this is the business for which he is seeking finance. He is also a small-scale trader.

Philemon is 46 years old, married and the father of six. His eldest child is 20, and the youngest three. Five of his children are in school, and he has no one else to look after. He was born in Rwanda and completed eight years of primary school.

Philemon started working with ACB S.A. in 2011 and is currently on his third loan cycle. The previous two loans were correctly repaid.

With the loan requested, he will purchase 40 kilograms of chemical fertilizer. The remainder will be used to pay his labourers. He does not foresee any difficulties repaying this loan, and will work as hard as possible to expand his agricultural business. 

Philemon's ambition is to become the region’s largest rice grower. At home, is aims are to educate his children and ensure they are well looked after.

loans.use: purchase 40kgs of chemical fertilizer and pay labourers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy general merchandise to sell, such as soap and salt.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is 22 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, 1 of whom is currently in school. For the past 4 years, Joan has been working hard to manage her small hotel that sells cooked food.

To help expand her business, Joan has requested a loan of 800000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more fresh food for cooking and reselling, and will help Joan to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her child. Joan hopes that in the future she will be able to to become a rich business woman. 

Joan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food to cook and resell.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en:
Joan is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kayunga in the Mukono region of Uganda. For the past 3 years, Joan has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Joan has requested a loan of 500000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fresh food for cooking and reselling. It will also help Joan to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her siblings. Joan hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business into a bigger restaurant. 

Joan is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more fresh food for cooking and reselling.

loans.name: Delys

texts.es: Delys compró muchos productos de belleza y acondicionó su local con su previo credikiva, en la actualidad está aplicando a un nuevo finaciamiento porque la temporada de Diciembre viene con mucho pedidos y su capital de trabajo resulta ser insuficiente para comprar productos de belleza como insumos para ofrecer servicios de mejoramiento de imagen en su sala de belleza y tambien para la venta; esta es la razón por la cual acude aun nuevo credikiva con el que comprará champoo, productos capilares, cosméticos cremas etc.
texts.en: Delys bought several beauty products and renovated her salon with her previous Kiva loan. She's currently applying for a new loan because December is approaching with a lot of orders and her working capital is not enough to purchase beauty products. She'll use them to offer beauty enhancement services at her beauty salon, and also for selling. That's the reason why she seeks a new Kiva loan, which she'll use to purchase shampoo, hair products, cosmetics, lotions, etc.

loans.use: to purchase shampoo, hair products, cosmetics, lotions, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy 60kgs of chemical fertilizer and pay labourers.

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 22 years old and lives in the Telavi district with his wife and child. He earns an income as a taxi driver and provides services to local people. George's income is not enough to provide food for a three-person family and, according to Credo estimates, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. George has decided to start a new business to supplement his income but his loan requests have been rejected several times by local financial institutions. He lacks experience with new business start-ups and does not qualify under income requirements. 

George is requesting a loan under the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and Credo. This loan program envisions providing start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the rural poor, who do not have access to many credit products as they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. George will use his loan to start a car wash.  He will purchase essential equipment and a vacuum cleaner. George will provide services to local community members and hopes to increase the monthly income of the family. His new business initiative will significantly improve the living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to start a car wash and purchase essential equipment and a vacuum cleaner

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 26-year-old youth client who is single and lives with six family members, three of whom are employed. He is from Iraq. Since 2010, Ahmad has owned a small grocery store where he sells soft drinks, juices, cheese, dairy products, detergents, and snacks. He has two employees. Ahmad has good experience in his field and is well-known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

Ahmad is requesting a 2,400 USD youth loan to renovate his grocery store. In the future, he hopes to grow his business and increase his profits to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to renovate his grocery store

loans.name: Maureen

texts.en:
Maureen is a 28-year-old married woman with three children. She lives in Masindi, Uganda. Maureen operates a beauty salon and has been able to buy land and pay school fees for her children with the income she has earned. She does not have adequate capital to purchase modern equipment to attract more customers.

Maureen is requesting a loan to buy synthetic hair and cosmetics for her salon. In the future, her dream is to modernize her salon and diversify her business to include farming.

loans.use: to buy synthetic hair and cosmetics for her salon

loans.name: Innocent

texts.en:
Innocent is a 54-year-old married man with four children. He lives in Kasese, Uganda. For the past 26 years, Innocent has been a teacher. He was inspired to become a teacher by his love of associating with young people. Innocent's major financial challenge is his low salary as he is unable to fully meet his daily expenses.

Innocent is requesting a loan to pay school fees for his children. In the future, he plans to venture into business to supplement his salary.

loans.use: to pay for school fees for his children

loans.name: Inga

texts.en:
Inga is 39 years old, married and lives in Kobuleti district with her husband and three children (14, 18 and 21 years old). Her husband works as a salesman and gets a monthly salary. Inga’s economic activity is a newly started small grocery store, where she sells different kinds of groceries. Inga requested a loan from local financial institutions for the business expansion, but without success. Her loan request was rejected because of her low income and insufficient experience in her business. 

However, her loan request was approved through a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The program provides start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. They do not have access to traditional credit products, being regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. Inga requested a loan to purchase basic groceries that customers often request. She plans to increase the turnover in her trade business gradually. This will raise the income of the family, which will be used to improve the family’s living conditions. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase basic groceries for her grocery store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase chemical fertilizers and pay labourers.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy food to sell.

loans.name: Kyanya Bakyara Thuwathikana Group

texts.en: Eddy is a fifty-two-year-old married woman with seven children living in Kasese, Uganda. She has been operating a retail business for twenty-two years and she has been able to buy land for farming with the proceeds. She began her business to be economically empowered. Inadequate capital and price fluctuations are her major challenges, while her dreams are to have a wholesale shop and venture into commercial farming. Eddy intends to use this loan to purchase soap and palm oil to sell. She is a member of the above-mentioned group, in which each member guarantees the other in accessing a loan.

loans.use: to purchase soap and palm oil to sell.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana is 42 years old, married and lives in Tbilisi with her husband and three children (11,17 and 21 years old). The younger children go to the local school. Nana’s economic activity is a newly started small store, where she sells different kinds of fruits and vegetables. Nana requested a loan from local financial institutions to expand her business, but without success. Her loan request was rejected because of her low income and insufficient experience in her business. 

However, her loan request was approved through a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The program provides start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. These people do not have access to traditional credit products, being regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of low income. Nana requested a loan purchase coffee grinder and coffee. She will sell coffee and offer grinding services to her clients. Nana plans to increase the turnover in her trade business gradually. This will raise the income of the family, which she will use to improve the family’s living conditions and finance the education of her child. She awaits your support.

loans.use: to purchase coffee and a coffee grinder.

loans.name: Leyne

texts.es: Leyne desde San Juan Nepomuceno está aplicando a su primer financiamiento con Kiva, pues va a prepararse para las fiestas de fin de año, época de gran movimiento comercial y en la que usualmente hace la mejor venta del año, pero sus recursos se encuentran en sus cuentas por cobrar, en manos de la clientela que le compra a crédito. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a un creikiva, primer finaciamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará ropa exterior interior y calzado informal; ella está muy segura de sus resultados positivos, al hacer esta inversión,  porque responderá a la demanda de sus clientes a los que mucho conoce, porque pertenecen a la misma población donde habita y tiene su negocio  desde hace 2 años, el cual nació  con el objetivo de generar ingresos; inició vendiendo mercancías variadas y esta actividad le ha funcionado como fuente de recursos para sostenerse a sus 20 años y resolver sus necesidades básicas y futuros sueños.  En la puerta de su casa tiene una pequeña vitrina, con la  que llama la atención de la gente, logrando que se acerque a comprar artículos varios, pero ella  principalmente vende ropa y calzado,  que compra en las ciudades de Barranquilla ciudad costera a 3 horas de su natal San Juan Nepomuceno y en la capital de Colombia : Bogotá. Sus clientes le pagan principalmente a crédito y muchas veces de contado, cuando por ejemplo son artículos más económicos, como la ropa interior. Su meta es continuar sus estudios,  pero más inmediatamente aumentar sus ventas,  para poder responder a esta necesidad y al sueño de algún día ser una profesional prestigiosa.
texts.en:
Leyne, who is from San Juan Nepomuceno, is applying for her first loan with Kiva to be ready for the year-end events that usually generate the highest sales of the year for businesses. Her working capital, though, is tied up in accounts receivable. She is seeking her first Kiva loan through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to buy clothing, underwear, and casual shoes. She is certain this investment will be successful because she will be meeting the needs of her regular customers, who live in the neighborhood where she has operated her business for two years. 

At age 20, she started selling a variety of merchandise to earn income, and the business funds her daily needs and her dreams for the future. There is a small display case in the doorway of her house to attract customers to buy her merchandise. Mostly, Leyne sells clothing and shoes that she buys in the coastal city of  Barranquilla, which is three hours from her native San Juan Nepomuceno, and in Bogotá, the capital of Colombia. Her customers usually pay on credit; sometimes they pay in cash for cheaper items such as underwear. Right now she wants to increase her sales, but her goal is to continue her education so that one day she can achieve her dream to have a prestigious career.

loans.use: to buy clothing, underwear, and casual shoes.

loans.name: Mzevinar

texts.en:
Mzevinar is 40 years old. She lives with her husband and 2 children in Batumi, West Georgia. Mzevinar is a cleaner and her daughter is a waitress in hotel; they both get monthly income. Mzevinar requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected every time because of her low income and family’s poor living conditions. According to Credo's estimations, the family belongs to the subsistence poor category. 

Because of her failure to get a traditional loan, Mzevinar requested a loan from Credo to start-up her family business. Her loan request was approved due to a new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. This start-up loan program provides business start-up and restart-up credits with soft conditions to the country's rural poor. These borrowers do not have access to credit products, for they are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income. With her loan, Mzevinar will renovate a flat, which she has bought to rent out. Because of tourism development in Batumi, Mzevinar believes that renovating this flat will help her earn income. This new business initiative, financed with a start-up loan from Kiva, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to renovate a flat to rent.

loans.name: Reyna

texts.es:
Reyna de 32 años, natural del distrito de Santa Rosa. Tiene por pareja a Zacarías padre de sus  3 menores hijos con quienes comparte muchas vivencias y juntos habitan en una calida vivienda hecha a base de madera. Durante muchos años se desempeñó como productora de cacao orgánico, pero al sufrir un temporal ataque de plagas se vio en la necesidad de abrir un nuevo negocio que es la crianza de aves de corral.
Lleva 1 año desempeñándose en el rubro y tras la venta de su primera crianza se siente muy motivada ya que las aves alcanzaron un buen tamaño. Le agrada mucho esta actividad debido a que siente tener una comprensión única con las aves y es algo sencillo con relación al duro trabajo en el campo y porque no requiere contar con mano de obra adicional logrando así obtener buenas ganancias.
Desea iniciar nuevamente con la crianza para su segunda temporada para el cual requiere adquirir gallinitas bebe y sacos de alimento natural con el cual espera brindarles toda la atención posible y repetir la primera buena crianza.
Siente que lo suyo es la crianza de animales es por ello que a futuro esta optando por dedicarse a la crianza de vacas y otros. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, muy agradecida se compromete a cumplir fielmente con el pago de sus cuotas para a futuro acceder a un crédito mayor. Con los 1,000 nuevos soles realizará la compra de gallinitas de corral así como reservar dinero para la compra de granos de maíz para la constante alimentación de las aves.
texts.en:
Reyna, 32, is from Santa Rosa District.  Her partner is Zacarías, the father of their three minor children she shares many life experiences with and who all live together in a cozy house made of Wood.  For many years she worked growing organic cocoa beans but when the crops were attacked by a seasonal pest infestation she had go into a new business: raising barnyard fowl.

She’s been in this line of work for a year and after selling her first batch of animals she feels motivated because the birds attained good growth.  She likes this activity very much because she feels she has a unique understanding of the birds and it’s somewhat easier than the hard field work she used to do and she also does not have to hire additional staff so her profits are good.

She wants to start raising a new group for the second season and needs to buy baby chicks and sacks of natural feed to provide them with the all the care necessary and repeat her initial good results.  She feels that her calling is raising animals which is why in future she wants to go into raising cows and others.

This is her first MFP loan and she’s very grateful and commits to faithfully make her payments so that she can access a larger loan in future.  She will use the 1,000 new soles to buy barnyard fowl chicks and also set aside some of the money to buy grains of corn for the constant feeding of the fowl.

loans.use: to buy chickens and corn.

loans.name: Amjad

texts.en:
Amjad is a 26-year-old youth client who is single and lives with five family members, two of whom are employed. He is from Iraq. Since 2011, Amjad has owned a small grocery store where he sells soft drinks, juices, cheese, dairy products, detergents, and snacks. He has one employee. Amjad has developed a lot of good experience in his field and is well-known in the surrounding area with an excellent reputation.

Amjad is requesting a 1,200 USD youth loan to design a new display window and to increase his inventory. In the future, he hopes to grow his business and increase his profits to provide his family with better living conditions.

loans.use: to design a new display window and to increase his inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothing to sell before the Christmas season

loans.name: Denis

texts.en:
Denis lives in the town of Nakifuma in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has one child. For the past 3 years, Denis has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells sugar, posho, flour, and other items. 

To help expand his business, Denis has requested a loan of 3000000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. He will use this loan to increase his inventory of sugar, all types of flour and salt. This increased inventory will help Denis generate greater profits and improve his standard of living. Denis hopes that in the future he will be able to start a mini-supermarket. 

Denis is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). This program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Denis who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to increase his inventory of sugar, all types of flour and salt.
